		<shortDescription>fortunately i got in for free</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>i was so hyped up to see this movie. from the day i first heard it was announced to the week of its release, it was the one movie i was actually looking forward to. buddy of mine that worked at our local cinema-plex got me in for free and i sat down with only the best of intentions. i knew something was wrong the minute the opening credits came up and "holy sh*t?! wheres the all to familiar Terminator theme by Brad Fiedel?" i almost wanted to cry. by the end of the movies i had more questions than just those to ask. like why did they send poor Arnold's model back to fight off the T-X? the t-800 vs. the t-1000 wasnt so bad and it put Arnold at a little disadvantage and made him have to outwit the thing. if they were even, then it wouldnt have been interesting. but the t-800 vs. the t-x wasnt even remotely fair. its like a toaster vs. a flamethrower. what the hell were the story writers thinking?acting wise, the movie was average. Arnold played his part as the emotionless cyborg excellently as usual. Nick Stahl was pretty convincing as the future leader John Connor and Claire Danes was just there. nothing really standing out in her role. Newcomer Kristanna Loken played the T-X very well. Unfortunately the new female terminator just didnt seem as terrifying as the previous terminators and really didnt give you that sense of hopelessness and despair as Robert Patrick's and Arnold's previous terminator roles did. you wanna be scared of the terminator, not drool over it. but i guess that was the whole point. drool and be scared at the same time.overall, Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines was an entertaining summer flick and one of the better big-budget action movies released in a while. the ending was one that made you think yet very dissapointing. kinda like terminator sorta kinda maybe 2.5. i think James Cameron's direction would have been much better. an average action flick with the Terminator name stamped on it.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>Quincey_P_Morris</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Perfect Summer Movie (Minor Spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Minor SpoilersTerminator 3 is exactly the type of movie that I like to see as part of the summer blockbuster season. It's loaded with incredible looking action, it's humorous , and it has a huge cheese factor. The storyline is only used just to get to the next explosion or the next joke. But even so, for the most part the story seemed right on par with the previous installments, and at the ending, it completely took off and a classic was born.In a huge departure from the previous installments, director Jonathan Mostow has taken the James Cameron-abandoned franchise and made it his own with a very exciting and thrilling film. I thought the ending of T3 was simply amazing and such a welcome change from the 'happy' ending that follows so many of the summer movies. Very courageous of Mostow as well, I might add.The films titanic budget is all up there on the screen and was used to great effect (minus Arnie's $30 million take of course).The action in this movie is truly the show stopper here. The sequence with the upending crane truck was absolutely staggering and completely blew my mind. The best car chase scene I have ever scene (or at least the most destructive). The hearse sequence, is also very noteworthy. The action sequences never let up and really demonstrate just how far along the advances in CGI, animatronics, and even make-up have come. Kudos to the always excellent work by Stan Winston with his T-X design and fully-functioning T-1 robots.I think that what many of the negative reviewers of this film take issue with is the lack of subtle humor that was so prevalent in the first two movies. The comedy was put into overdrive for this film, as Arnie delivers more one-liners than ever, some of them absolutely atrocious. But if you can just laugh them off, you'll still be in for a great ride. The humourous cameo by Dr. Silberman was a nice touch.Schwarzenegger however to my surprise, is still very convincing as the cybernetic organism that he first played almost twenty years ago, and his physique for the most part is as it was back in 1984, although he does look a little smaller. Kristanna Loken did a great job too as the female T-X, but I still think that Robert Patrick as the merciless T-1000 is still the most ruthless of the villain Terminators.Nick Stahl and Claire Danes as John Connor and Kate Brewster respectively, also put in decent performances. Connor does look like a grungy vagrant, but a liquid metal terminator coming through the future ten years ago solely to kill you, is bound to be somewhat traumatic for the guy, and might just cause him to live an alternate lifestyle.All in all, a very entertaining popcorn flick. Highly recommended if you enjoy action movies, or the Terminator film franchise (if you can digest some minor plot holes). I can't wait for the DVD, and I hope that T4 gets the greenlight too, with Mostow once again at the helm.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>lambiepie-2</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Popcorn Movie...nothing more, nothing less</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It seems like the problem with a lot of reviews is that many are forgetting this series is called: "The Terminator", and that is what is continuing to happen in Terminator 3."John Connor" is looking to be terminated by the machines who rule existence in the future -- come heck or high water. That is THEIR plan which is the whole point of these films. Send a machine, or machines, to kill John Connor or to possibly SAVE John Connor. Once you get that in your brain, nothing else matters. What we are seeing is what occurs in and around John's life as this happens and why these machines NEED for it to happen. Remember that, and you may -- or may not -- enjoy, Terminator 3.With that in mind, who cares if Arnold is there or not. He's a lovely "familiar" addition, but by no means the make or break all of the central idea. This franchise CAN go on without him. Arnold's character (if you want to call it that) is a TYPE of machine model that will either save or destroy John Connor. Depends on who's programming what at which time...This terminator MODEL has the same face. Arnold's. Do not be surprised if the next Terminator movie (God Forbid, hut hey, money is money) has several Arnolds in it and ya don't know which is "good" or "bad". There are other advanced models sent as we now are aware such as...the "Robert Patrick" model and this Barbie doll from a Rodeo drive window. (As a resident of Beverly Hills I take offense, she should have been at least 53 years old, and should have came out of a plastic surgeon's chair as she was getting rhinoplasty/breast augmentation or a tummy tuck. Now that would have been a fun film!)There will be many more sent, etc...but don't forget the point --- that the Arnold model terminator is a "dependable", "stronger" model even if its older than the others send to do the job of terminating John Connor at various ages and stages in the game.Heck yes, I miss James Cameron's work, but I would have been disappointed if he went into this mire of Hollywood Franchise Business at this stage in his career. Same with Linda Hamilton. Onwards and upwards, I always say.Mr. Mostow has HIS chance now and he's done exactly what was needed of him. Studio execs are applauding. To produce an adolescent testosterone driven Holiday release popcorn movie heavy on explosions, action and pyrotechnics and thin on plot, story and series continuity.MAJOR Terminator fans will be scratching their heads at a lot of this installment, younger viewers will be thrilled and give the film praises because it's all the old Hollywood rape your pockets for the summer shuffle and jive of "smoke and mirrors action". On the other hand, the ending (like everyone else I wont give away) but for me, well worth the price I paid to get in this weekend to see it (and that was on a matinée.)Terminator 3 - Rise of the Machines (Which by the way, is the best title since "South Park - Bigger, Longer and Uncut") is nothing more than some popcorn selling "entertainment" to kill a long drawn out holiday weekend and another, installment in "the Life of John Connor, human savior."</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>ksagendo-1</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Good, not great sequel to the series</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let me start off by saying the first two Terminators are among my all time favorites. I left the theaters amazed and thought the ticket was well worth it. I'll always own copies on tape (and now need to purchase the DVD's with the extra features).I can't really say that for "T3". While there was good action and Kristiana Loken was very good as the T-X, I thought there could've been more new ground to cover. How about a more extended look at the future, after the nuclear bombs have dropped and the humans have to fight the machines? How about seeing John Conner as the great military leader he supposedly is? Or seeing how the terminators were first created? Maybe we'll see those concepts in "T4" assuming there will be one. There can only be so many times these machines can go back to track down John Conner and whoever he's associated with. Overall this wasn't bad, but after 12 years of waiting and hoping for another sequel I expected a little more.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>Masterfulks</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Terminator is back on top!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It was pretty good. Some will fault T3 because of the lacking of some characters, but it does not hurt this film. It has more plot than T1, or T2 combined.The lack of Cameron does not bother me at all. It also has several twists that give it more depth than the previous Terminator movies. The special effects were great, well above the Matrix movies if you ask me. CGI use was nice and not overdone.Arnold is back in top shape for this one as well. I really hope we see a T4. I think it was not a good time to release T3. My theatre was pretty empty on Friday night (the 4th of July). I think a lot of people were out to other Holiday parties. I guess we'll know on later on.More action, more destruction, more plot, more Terminator, go see it!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>elsilencioesdeoro</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Back to back home runs with T2 and T3</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Terminator was a great movie in it's own right. It was an 80s horror film that introduced many of us to Arnold (those of us who hadn't seen Conan). However, Terminator lacked intricacy in it's writing and plot. That problem was quickly resolved in Terminator 2, which showed us that there was so much more to the future, Skynet, and Cyberdyne systems than we thought. Terminator 2 not only brought more story to the table, but more action. It also introduced us to a couple of great actors (Robert Patrick, Edward Furlong). The long anticipated Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines picked up right where T2 left off. Where can you go from T2, some may ask? The story was already brought to a conclusion, right? Wrong. Just when you thought you knew everything, you finally realize that you hardly anything. T3 does exactly what T2 did for Terminator. It takes us even DEEPER into the world of the Terminators and answers a lot of questions that many of us had after T2. The creators of this movie took a series that seemingly had it's strings tied up and created a whole new chapter that is brilliant in it's depth. Not only does T3 bring a great story to the table just as T2 did, but it too brings blockbuster action. After watching T3, it's arguably the best action movie of this summer. Mostow does a great job of filling in for Cameron (we miss you James!). It's truly enjoyable to watch action movies as they used to be made...without much aid of computers. Matrix Reloaded was great...but it relied heavily on computer imagery. Most of T3's action is genuine, jaw dropping stunts. And just as T2 introduced us to new Hollywood faces, so too does T3. Nick Stahl, who plays John Connor, has a great deal of acting talent. He brings his own touch to the character of Connor, now 20 something. We see a whole new side of Connor, very different from the one we saw in T2. In T2, Connor was a rebellious teen who just wanted to have a good time with his friends at the arcade. T3 shows us a worn down, depressed, junkie. Stahl did an excellent job of pulling off the role. He reminded me very much of Tobey Macguire in this movie, perhaps due to his narration and soft-spoken demeanor. We're also introduced to Kristanna Loken, who plays the T-X. It's hard to gauge whether anyone who's recruited to play a terminator truly has any acting talent. The role just doesn't do actors any justice. They must literally constrain their acting talents to the confines of a robot. We obviously know, now, that Schwartzenegger and Patrick were better actors than their terminator roles made them out to be. So too will be the case, I believe, with Loken. Not just anyone can play the role of a terminator. It takes a certain breed and I believe the creators of T3 did a great job of casting. All in all, I give this movie a 9.5, but seeing as that's not a choice, I just rounded up to 10. Bash me if you wish, but I suggest you see the movie. It really is worth the time and money. It delivers in every possible way.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>magiclady1</username>

He hasn't changed at all from the original movie. All the actors were good. Would see again and for me thats saying a lot. Recommeded to all my friends.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>belikemichael.com</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Mediocrity Unacceptable for a Terminator Film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Terminator films are supposed to rule. Even in the age where sequels, by definition, suck, somehow Terminator 2 still ruled (maybe even more than the first). A standard was set, they aimed high and they hit higher with strong characters, a strong story and excellent effects.T-3 did NOT rule, however. There was virtually NO story, the special effects were completely derivative of T2 (couldn't the cgi geeks come up with something better?), the characters were so devoid of depth that you almost wished them dead and the authors copped out by simply dismissing the well crafted plot of the earlier Terminator films.The introduction of cute one liners from T2 was so overused in T-3 that it got stale quicker than a "Charlie's Angels" sequel. The film makers of T-3 simply cashed in on a proven formula and didn't seem to care one bit about fumbling on one of the best film storylines ever created. I, for one, had expected that they would have spent much more time on the story and had done justice to the prior films. Mediocrity does not belong in Terminator films;they deserve much, much more. 6/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>cainam</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent! Best movie of 2003</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Out of all the big movies released (X2, Matrix 2, Hulk, etc) this one is the best! Non-stop action, a solid cast with top-notch acting, and a very good ending. I didn't actually expect much since Cameron wasn't directing T3 but it turned out to be a pleasant surprise! See this in the theatre while you can!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>Quincey_P_Morris</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Perfect Summer Movie (Minor Spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Minor SpoilersTerminator 3 is exactly the type of movie that I like to see as part of the summer blockbuster season. It's loaded with incredible looking action, it's humorous , and it has a huge cheese factor. The storyline is only used just to get to the next explosion or the next joke. But even so, for the most part the story seemed right on par with the previous installments, and at the ending, it completely took off and a classic was born.In a huge departure from the previous installments, director Jonathan Mostow has taken the James Cameron-abandoned franchise and made it his own with a very exciting and thrilling film. I thought the ending of T3 was simply amazing and such a welcome change from the 'happy' ending that follows so many of the summer movies. Very courageous of Mostow as well, I might add.The films titanic budget is all up there on the screen and was used to great effect (minus Arnie's $30 million take of course).The action in this movie is truly the show stopper here. The sequence with the upending crane truck was absolutely staggering and completely blew my mind. The best car chase scene I have ever scene (or at least the most destructive). The hearse sequence, is also very noteworthy. The action sequences never let up and really demonstrate just how far along the advances in CGI, animatronics, and even make-up have come. Kudos to the always excellent work by Stan Winston with his T-X design and fully-functioning T-1 robots.I think that what many of the negative reviewers of this film take issue with is the lack of subtle humor that was so prevalent in the first two movies. The comedy was put into overdrive for this film, as Arnie delivers more one-liners than ever, some of them absolutely atrocious. But if you can just laugh them off, you'll still be in for a great ride. The humourous cameo by Dr. Silberman was a nice touch.Schwarzenegger however to my surprise, is still very convincing as the cybernetic organism that he first played almost twenty years ago, and his physique for the most part is as it was back in 1984, although he does look a little smaller. Kristanna Loken did a great job too as the female T-X, but I still think that Robert Patrick as the merciless T-1000 is still the most ruthless of the villain Terminators.Nick Stahl and Claire Danes as John Connor and Kate Brewster respectively, also put in decent performances. Connor does look like a grungy vagrant, but a liquid metal terminator coming through the future ten years ago solely to kill you, is bound to be somewhat traumatic for the guy, and might just cause him to live an alternate lifestyle.All in all, a very entertaining popcorn flick. Highly recommended if you enjoy action movies, or the Terminator film franchise (if you can digest some minor plot holes). I can't wait for the DVD, and I hope that T4 gets the greenlight too, with Mostow once again at the helm.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>lambiepie-2</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Popcorn Movie...nothing more, nothing less</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It seems like the problem with a lot of reviews is that many are forgetting this series is called: "The Terminator", and that is what is continuing to happen in Terminator 3."John Connor" is looking to be terminated by the machines who rule existence in the future -- come heck or high water. That is THEIR plan which is the whole point of these films. Send a machine, or machines, to kill John Connor or to possibly SAVE John Connor. Once you get that in your brain, nothing else matters. What we are seeing is what occurs in and around John's life as this happens and why these machines NEED for it to happen. Remember that, and you may -- or may not -- enjoy, Terminator 3.With that in mind, who cares if Arnold is there or not. He's a lovely "familiar" addition, but by no means the make or break all of the central idea. This franchise CAN go on without him. Arnold's character (if you want to call it that) is a TYPE of machine model that will either save or destroy John Connor. Depends on who's programming what at which time...This terminator MODEL has the same face. Arnold's. Do not be surprised if the next Terminator movie (God Forbid, hut hey, money is money) has several Arnolds in it and ya don't know which is "good" or "bad". There are other advanced models sent as we now are aware such as...the "Robert Patrick" model and this Barbie doll from a Rodeo drive window. (As a resident of Beverly Hills I take offense, she should have been at least 53 years old, and should have came out of a plastic surgeon's chair as she was getting rhinoplasty/breast augmentation or a tummy tuck. Now that would have been a fun film!)There will be many more sent, etc...but don't forget the point --- that the Arnold model terminator is a "dependable", "stronger" model even if its older than the others send to do the job of terminating John Connor at various ages and stages in the game.Heck yes, I miss James Cameron's work, but I would have been disappointed if he went into this mire of Hollywood Franchise Business at this stage in his career. Same with Linda Hamilton. Onwards and upwards, I always say.Mr. Mostow has HIS chance now and he's done exactly what was needed of him. Studio execs are applauding. To produce an adolescent testosterone driven Holiday release popcorn movie heavy on explosions, action and pyrotechnics and thin on plot, story and series continuity.MAJOR Terminator fans will be scratching their heads at a lot of this installment, younger viewers will be thrilled and give the film praises because it's all the old Hollywood rape your pockets for the summer shuffle and jive of "smoke and mirrors action". On the other hand, the ending (like everyone else I wont give away) but for me, well worth the price I paid to get in this weekend to see it (and that was on a matinée.)Terminator 3 - Rise of the Machines (Which by the way, is the best title since "South Park - Bigger, Longer and Uncut") is nothing more than some popcorn selling "entertainment" to kill a long drawn out holiday weekend and another, installment in "the Life of John Connor, human savior."</fullReview>
	</review>

There are other advanced models sent as we now are aware such as...the "Robert Patrick" model and this Barbie doll from a Rodeo drive window. (As a resident of Beverly Hills I take offense, she should have been at least 53 years old, and should have came out of a plastic surgeon's chair as she was getting rhinoplasty/breast augmentation or a tummy tuck. Now that would have been a fun film!)There will be many more sent, etc...but don't forget the point --- that the Arnold model terminator is a "dependable", "stronger" model even if its older than the others send to do the job of terminating John Connor at various ages and stages in the game.Heck yes, I miss James Cameron's work, but I would have been disappointed if he went into this mire of Hollywood Franchise Business at this stage in his career. Same with Linda Hamilton. Onwards and upwards, I always say.Mr. Mostow has HIS chance now and he's done exactly what was needed of him. Studio execs are applauding. To produce an adolescent testosterone driven Holiday release popcorn movie heavy on explosions, action and pyrotechnics and thin on plot, story and series continuity.MAJOR Terminator fans will be scratching their heads at a lot of this installment, younger viewers will be thrilled and give the film praises because it's all the old Hollywood rape your pockets for the summer shuffle and jive of "smoke and mirrors action". On the other hand, the ending (like everyone else I wont give away) but for me, well worth the price I paid to get in this weekend to see it (and that was on a matinée.)Terminator 3 - Rise of the Machines (Which by the way, is the best title since "South Park - Bigger, Longer and Uncut") is nothing more than some popcorn selling "entertainment" to kill a long drawn out holiday weekend and another, installment in "the Life of John Connor, human savior."</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>ksagendo-1</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Good, not great sequel to the series</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let me start off by saying the first two Terminators are among my all time favorites. I left the theaters amazed and thought the ticket was well worth it. I'll always own copies on tape (and now need to purchase the DVD's with the extra features).I can't really say that for "T3". While there was good action and Kristiana Loken was very good as the T-X, I thought there could've been more new ground to cover. How about a more extended look at the future, after the nuclear bombs have dropped and the humans have to fight the machines? How about seeing John Conner as the great military leader he supposedly is? Or seeing how the terminators were first created? Maybe we'll see those concepts in "T4" assuming there will be one. There can only be so many times these machines can go back to track down John Conner and whoever he's associated with. Overall this wasn't bad, but after 12 years of waiting and hoping for another sequel I expected a little more.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Terminator is back on top!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It was pretty good. Some will fault T3 because of the lacking of some characters, but it does not hurt this film. It has more plot than T1, or T2 combined.The lack of Cameron does not bother me at all. It also has several twists that give it more depth than the previous Terminator movies. The special effects were great, well above the Matrix movies if you ask me. CGI use was nice and not overdone.Arnold is back in top shape for this one as well. I really hope we see a T4. I think it was not a good time to release T3. My theatre was pretty empty on Friday night (the 4th of July). I think a lot of people were out to other Holiday parties. I guess we'll know on later on.More action, more destruction, more plot, more Terminator, go see it!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>elsilencioesdeoro</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Back to back home runs with T2 and T3</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Terminator was a great movie in it's own right. It was an 80s horror film that introduced many of us to Arnold (those of us who hadn't seen Conan). However, Terminator lacked intricacy in it's writing and plot. That problem was quickly resolved in Terminator 2, which showed us that there was so much more to the future, Skynet, and Cyberdyne systems than we thought. Terminator 2 not only brought more story to the table, but more action. It also introduced us to a couple of great actors (Robert Patrick, Edward Furlong). The long anticipated Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines picked up right where T2 left off. Where can you go from T2, some may ask? The story was already brought to a conclusion, right? Wrong. Just when you thought you knew everything, you finally realize that you hardly anything. T3 does exactly what T2 did for Terminator. It takes us even DEEPER into the world of the Terminators and answers a lot of questions that many of us had after T2. The creators of this movie took a series that seemingly had it's strings tied up and created a whole new chapter that is brilliant in it's depth. Not only does T3 bring a great story to the table just as T2 did, but it too brings blockbuster action. After watching T3, it's arguably the best action movie of this summer. Mostow does a great job of filling in for Cameron (we miss you James!). It's truly enjoyable to watch action movies as they used to be made...without much aid of computers. Matrix Reloaded was great...but it relied heavily on computer imagery. Most of T3's action is genuine, jaw dropping stunts. And just as T2 introduced us to new Hollywood faces, so too does T3. Nick Stahl, who plays John Connor, has a great deal of acting talent. He brings his own touch to the character of Connor, now 20 something. We see a whole new side of Connor, very different from the one we saw in T2. In T2, Connor was a rebellious teen who just wanted to have a good time with his friends at the arcade. T3 shows us a worn down, depressed, junkie. Stahl did an excellent job of pulling off the role. He reminded me very much of Tobey Macguire in this movie, perhaps due to his narration and soft-spoken demeanor. We're also introduced to Kristanna Loken, who plays the T-X. It's hard to gauge whether anyone who's recruited to play a terminator truly has any acting talent. The role just doesn't do actors any justice. They must literally constrain their acting talents to the confines of a robot. We obviously know, now, that Schwartzenegger and Patrick were better actors than their terminator roles made them out to be. So too will be the case, I believe, with Loken. Not just anyone can play the role of a terminator. It takes a certain breed and I believe the creators of T3 did a great job of casting. All in all, I give this movie a 9.5, but seeing as that's not a choice, I just rounded up to 10. Bash me if you wish, but I suggest you see the movie. It really is worth the time and money. It delivers in every possible way.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

He hasn't changed at all from the original movie. All the actors were good. Would see again and for me thats saying a lot. Recommeded to all my friends.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>Quincey_P_Morris</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Perfect Summer Movie (Minor Spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Minor SpoilersTerminator 3 is exactly the type of movie that I like to see as part of the summer blockbuster season. It's loaded with incredible looking action, it's humorous , and it has a huge cheese factor. The storyline is only used just to get to the next explosion or the next joke. But even so, for the most part the story seemed right on par with the previous installments, and at the ending, it completely took off and a classic was born.In a huge departure from the previous installments, director Jonathan Mostow has taken the James Cameron-abandoned franchise and made it his own with a very exciting and thrilling film. I thought the ending of T3 was simply amazing and such a welcome change from the 'happy' ending that follows so many of the summer movies. Very courageous of Mostow as well, I might add.The films titanic budget is all up there on the screen and was used to great effect (minus Arnie's $30 million take of course).The action in this movie is truly the show stopper here. The sequence with the upending crane truck was absolutely staggering and completely blew my mind. The best car chase scene I have ever scene (or at least the most destructive). The hearse sequence, is also very noteworthy. The action sequences never let up and really demonstrate just how far along the advances in CGI, animatronics, and even make-up have come. Kudos to the always excellent work by Stan Winston with his T-X design and fully-functioning T-1 robots.I think that what many of the negative reviewers of this film take issue with is the lack of subtle humor that was so prevalent in the first two movies. The comedy was put into overdrive for this film, as Arnie delivers more one-liners than ever, some of them absolutely atrocious. But if you can just laugh them off, you'll still be in for a great ride. The humourous cameo by Dr. Silberman was a nice touch.Schwarzenegger however to my surprise, is still very convincing as the cybernetic organism that he first played almost twenty years ago, and his physique for the most part is as it was back in 1984, although he does look a little smaller. Kristanna Loken did a great job too as the female T-X, but I still think that Robert Patrick as the merciless T-1000 is still the most ruthless of the villain Terminators.Nick Stahl and Claire Danes as John Connor and Kate Brewster respectively, also put in decent performances. Connor does look like a grungy vagrant, but a liquid metal terminator coming through the future ten years ago solely to kill you, is bound to be somewhat traumatic for the guy, and might just cause him to live an alternate lifestyle.All in all, a very entertaining popcorn flick. Highly recommended if you enjoy action movies, or the Terminator film franchise (if you can digest some minor plot holes). I can't wait for the DVD, and I hope that T4 gets the greenlight too, with Mostow once again at the helm.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>lambiepie-2</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Popcorn Movie...nothing more, nothing less</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It seems like the problem with a lot of reviews is that many are forgetting this series is called: "The Terminator", and that is what is continuing to happen in Terminator 3."John Connor" is looking to be terminated by the machines who rule existence in the future -- come heck or high water. That is THEIR plan which is the whole point of these films. Send a machine, or machines, to kill John Connor or to possibly SAVE John Connor. Once you get that in your brain, nothing else matters. What we are seeing is what occurs in and around John's life as this happens and why these machines NEED for it to happen. Remember that, and you may -- or may not -- enjoy, Terminator 3.With that in mind, who cares if Arnold is there or not. He's a lovely "familiar" addition, but by no means the make or break all of the central idea. This franchise CAN go on without him. Arnold's character (if you want to call it that) is a TYPE of machine model that will either save or destroy John Connor. Depends on who's programming what at which time...This terminator MODEL has the same face. Arnold's. Do not be surprised if the next Terminator movie (God Forbid, hut hey, money is money) has several Arnolds in it and ya don't know which is "good" or "bad". There are other advanced models sent as we now are aware such as...the "Robert Patrick" model and this Barbie doll from a Rodeo drive window. (As a resident of Beverly Hills I take offense, she should have been at least 53 years old, and should have came out of a plastic surgeon's chair as she was getting rhinoplasty/breast augmentation or a tummy tuck. Now that would have been a fun film!)There will be many more sent, etc...but don't forget the point --- that the Arnold model terminator is a "dependable", "stronger" model even if its older than the others send to do the job of terminating John Connor at various ages and stages in the game.Heck yes, I miss James Cameron's work, but I would have been disappointed if he went into this mire of Hollywood Franchise Business at this stage in his career. Same with Linda Hamilton. Onwards and upwards, I always say.Mr. Mostow has HIS chance now and he's done exactly what was needed of him. Studio execs are applauding. To produce an adolescent testosterone driven Holiday release popcorn movie heavy on explosions, action and pyrotechnics and thin on plot, story and series continuity.MAJOR Terminator fans will be scratching their heads at a lot of this installment, younger viewers will be thrilled and give the film praises because it's all the old Hollywood rape your pockets for the summer shuffle and jive of "smoke and mirrors action". On the other hand, the ending (like everyone else I wont give away) but for me, well worth the price I paid to get in this weekend to see it (and that was on a matinée.)Terminator 3 - Rise of the Machines (Which by the way, is the best title since "South Park - Bigger, Longer and Uncut") is nothing more than some popcorn selling "entertainment" to kill a long drawn out holiday weekend and another, installment in "the Life of John Connor, human savior."</fullReview>
	</review>

It delivers in every possible way.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>lwjoslin</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Rock'em sock'em robots</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Terminator 3" is a worthy successor because it continues the series in exactly the same way that, say, "Alien3" did not. Whereas "A3" basically said "forget those earlier two movies" and did something disastrously different, "T3" follows through on situations set up in the first two installations, neither contradicting anything we were told earlier, nor pulling any crucial but previously unknown info out of a hat. (Think "Halloween II": "Gee, we forgot to tell you that Laurie Strode is Michael Myers' sister." Never have bought that. None of that nonsense here.) "T3" sets up familiar scenes--e.g., Arnold arrives naked from the future and has to find some clothes--then plays against expectations, often humorously, to resolve them.Linda Hamilton's Sarah Connor is absent, but still has her own contribution to make. "T1" was about Sarah; "T2" was about Sarah and her son John; "T3" is about reluctant hero John. But since the tuff-heroine aspect is so important to this series, that baton is passed to former teenager Claire Danes, who's surprisingly capable as a pi$$ed-off action chick.Arnold's Terminator--hostile in "T1", helpful in "T2"--is still helpful here, if a bit chattier. His matter-of-fact transmission of useful info, and his timely observations of human nature as he's been programmed to understand it ("Anger is more useful than despair"), make use of Arnold's gift of deadpan comedy. And the terminatrix, the TX, played by 23-year-old Kristanna Loken, is an absolute icepick. Combining the deadliest aspects of the earlier models' hardened skeleton AND liquid-metal body, this one adds built-in weapons systems and the ability to remote-control other machines. Loken has only two facial expressions here: a total blank, and a go-to-hell version of a Mona Lisa smirk. Both expressions are chillingly unblinking. Brrr!Ignore the whiners who are going on about how bad a movie they think this is; they're the equivalent of Comic Book Guy on "The Simpsons" saying, "Worst episode EVER!" Killer robots, nuclear peril, over-the-top vehicle chases, and a two-fisted action heroine: what more could you ask? Surprisingly downbeat ending, all but guaranteeing a "T4." Bring it on.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>thesundance14</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>More of the same but to fans it is still ok!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What can one say about the same story told a different way. I mean we all know what happens and how and...well it is somehow still ok. I gave the movie a "5" and that is better than most this summer. Arnold S. is getting a bit long of tooth but he still looks pretty formidable. The rest is fairly fragile stuff in the plot department so I won't risk any "spoilers" but let us agree that the story isn't much. The action is up to current standards of exploding cars , buildings, people etc..But just once I would like someone to clue me in on the problem of how these super terminators can EVER lose. Nothing stops them so how would humans ever win even in the future?There is a hint in this movie and I am going to assume that the creators of this situation have pondered that problem and that will be visited in Terminator "4"?I can't really see to much to change in the format. It is what it IS! The formula works and why change it? For fans, and I am one, it is great.A great movie in form and substance it isn't, but who cares. "Hasta la vista Baby!"</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>jayfril</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>I'm baffled by the good reviews</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Poor poor James Cameron. This director didn't know what the heck he was doing. what was up with arnold saying "talk to the hand" or putting on some elton john shades? this movie lacks originality, suspense, a hardcore edge to it, a good soundtrack, and in my personal opinion, i thought arnold was a jerk in this movie. you almost wanted him to self terminate at the end. after the first 15 minutes of this movie, my stomach started churning with the way they mutilated this great film. the way they overlooked the story of the first two and just decided to create an all new plot to this one. and don't expect this film to be a great trilogy, its gonna be sequel garbage now.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>Ben (SchockerGD@aol.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The sequel that breaks the trilogy curse!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've been waiting 12 years for a new Terminator movie. Having watched T-1 and T-2 roughly 50 times each, I would consider myself a huge Terminator fan.This movie delivers the best movie of the year, and its doubtful very many movies could top this (aside from possibly ROTK, should it be good).John Mostow provides an interesting, new perspective on the franchise. Having been dissapointed with most of Camerons recent work, I am very glad he did this movie.The acting in the movie is pure gold, some of the best active I've seen. Arnold, Nick, Kristanna and Claire prove to be equal to any of the actors in the previous versious of the franchise.Action scenes are equal to both T-1 and T-2 in terms of intensity, possibly surpasing both.The pacing of the movie is very well done. Having been saddened by the poor job on Matrix : Reloaded, this movie (aside from a 5 second scene) has excellent pacing. DO NOT expect to get a chance to get up and goto the bathroom.I've read that some film critics claim that this Terminator doesn't have a story, nor a heart (compared to either of the earlier movies) is rather wrong. The theme of the movie is different from T-1 and T-2.Unlike T-1 and T-2, which have messages of hope during horrible circumstances, T-3 heart lies in inevitability, fate and destiny. John's portrayl of hopelessness is excellent.*Possible Spoilers*The movie does take about 15 minutes to start up, but after that, is excellent. The direction of how the machines take over is brilliant. I was stunned at the portrayl of the actual rise of the machines. Even though there is a lack of future war scenes, the movie makes up in the beginning of the war. I doubt that any director could do a better job.The only complaints I could have in the movie is the 5 second scene where Arnold puts on his glasses for the first time, which was humorous, but not needed. As well as the fact the movie didn't quite have the B-rated sheen that the first 2 had.I was suprised at 2 things which pleased me, the suspence and violence. Mostow did a better job with these 2 things than either Terminator.*End possible Spoilers*Having said all that, I'd look at it this way, on a scale of 1-10T-1 = 9.75 T-2 = 9.30 T-3 = 8.75-9.00Go see this movie, and if you've seen it, see it again!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>david77</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>film sinks under its own weight</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Having seen all three of the Terminator films as an adult, I've been progressively disappointed as the movies have come along. The first was by far the best, with real characters, a great story idea, and a solid script. The second, Judgment Day, presented a great chase sequence, but progressed poorly thereafter with weak acting and a script that steadily worsened. While the special effects were amazing at the time, the film failed where it counts most: the appearance of sympathetic characters. This last installment, which hopefully will indeed be the last, is easily the weakest in the series with very poor acting, and a script that relies mostly on special effects and chase scenes. The attempts at humor are badly needed in this movie, which was borderline boring. Even Arnold, sorry to say, seems tired of his character. With all its heavy machinery, the film sinks under its own weight.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>nderrick</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Arnold is damn funny</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie is awesome. Terminator is not about man against machine, it is not about the end of the world, it IS about one liners spoken in an austrian accent by a man who could at one point bench two of you put together. I laughed so hard I almost got kicked out of the theatre. By the way, cameron is the wrong guy for terminator. he is too serious and deep.The new director finally realized terminator's potential as a comedy, and exploited arnold's arnoldness to create the most lighthearted and funny terminator yet. It is too bad that all three weren't like this. Anyone who complains about his movie is a loser who can't lighten up and just have a good time. This is the best arnold flick since "Last Action Hero".</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>andrew9069</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A mere segue for T4?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>OK, you know what? Arnie can't carry a movie with the Terminator shtick anymore... it's just gotten TOO old. You gotta give him credit for looking so good at his age, but all the one liners he's forced to utter seem so contrived and derivative (as does the majority of this movie). And that opening sunglasses gag?!... Gimme a break!It was Edward Furlong and Linda Hamilton's energy &amp; desperation that brought T2 home, and their absence is acutely felt here (not to mention James Cameron's story telling and direction). I'm sure Furlong's real life personal challenges could have been incorporated to make John Connor's current state that much more striking... but oh, that would be too "risky" for such a cash-cow franchise. Clare Danes is the only actor here that could have generated some real empathy and humanity in this movie, but the poor writing does not ask her to.Robert Patrick's liquid-metal Terminator was excellent in T2 (still gives me the creeps just thinking about it) and his abilities &amp; limitations really added to the story and made some kind of sense. Kristanna Loken's coolness was great and her TerminatriX had real potential (should have had more sexy/gory scenes) but was ultimately derivative, as well. In addition, I didn't buy her upgraded terminator-ability of molting specific body parts into complicated machinery, and even less the idea that they could be permanently "damaged". (The story suffers when the writers don't follow their own rules.) God knows what unbelievable gimmick they'll come up with for T4, to try to out do the T-X!The action scenes were impressive, but I've grown tired of chase scenes pretty much altogether, each one trying to out do the last... they're just silly (e.g. Matrix Reloaded)... try spending the same time advancing the plot! (The last time I saw a decent chase scene was Ronin.) On top of that, they must have had wheels on the crane spreaders for that thing not to completely tip over right away!The only part that was really new and interesting was the end, at the military research facility, with the prototype robot tanks and planes running amok, but that was like only 10 minutes! There should also have been much more interaction with Colonel(?) Brewster, instead of killing him off as soon as they get to the research facility. It also made ABSOLUTELY NO SENSE that there were no military personnel manning that VIP bomb shelter... Very weak. However, I did like the CGI of nuclear missiles and explosions, but they didn't play up the Apocalypse enough... don't want to use up too much T4 material, I guess.Since this movie does a complete 1-80 with the deterministic aspect of fate (I thought "Fate is what you make it"?), it is a lot less hopeful than T1 &amp; T2 were. The only positive aspect about this new storyline is the relationship between John Connor and Kate Brewster, which everyone seems to like.With the amount of money they spent and the potential of the Terminator/Skynet premise, I was very much disappointed. This movie has its moments and could have been great, but it felt more like an expensive pilot for a post-doomsday TV series, and ends too early, just as things start to get interesting. Hopefully, they'll hire some real storytellers for the inevitable T4 for which this movie appears to be a mere segue. Rating for this `genre', given T2 is a 10/10: 6.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

Look for the scene with the psychiatrist - he is also in the second movie but the humor will be lost on you if you don't notice that.</fullReview>

This movie was obviously done only to make more money for it really lacked CREATIVITY and lacked ORIGINALITY. The Actor who plays John Connor does not look like the younger John Connor of part 2 at all. Very sloppy things like this were prevalent in this movie. Only for Sci-Fi action fans and big fans of the lead actors......</fullReview>

		<username>Ben (SchockerGD@aol.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The sequel that breaks the trilogy curse!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've been waiting 12 years for a new Terminator movie. Having watched T-1 and T-2 roughly 50 times each, I would consider myself a huge Terminator fan.This movie delivers the best movie of the year, and its doubtful very many movies could top this (aside from possibly ROTK, should it be good).John Mostow provides an interesting, new perspective on the franchise. Having been dissapointed with most of Camerons recent work, I am very glad he did this movie.The acting in the movie is pure gold, some of the best active I've seen. Arnold, Nick, Kristanna and Claire prove to be equal to any of the actors in the previous versious of the franchise.Action scenes are equal to both T-1 and T-2 in terms of intensity, possibly surpasing both.The pacing of the movie is very well done. Having been saddened by the poor job on Matrix : Reloaded, this movie (aside from a 5 second scene) has excellent pacing. DO NOT expect to get a chance to get up and goto the bathroom.I've read that some film critics claim that this Terminator doesn't have a story, nor a heart (compared to either of the earlier movies) is rather wrong. The theme of the movie is different from T-1 and T-2.Unlike T-1 and T-2, which have messages of hope during horrible circumstances, T-3 heart lies in inevitability, fate and destiny. John's portrayl of hopelessness is excellent.*Possible Spoilers*The movie does take about 15 minutes to start up, but after that, is excellent. The direction of how the machines take over is brilliant. I was stunned at the portrayl of the actual rise of the machines. Even though there is a lack of future war scenes, the movie makes up in the beginning of the war. I doubt that any director could do a better job.The only complaints I could have in the movie is the 5 second scene where Arnold puts on his glasses for the first time, which was humorous, but not needed. As well as the fact the movie didn't quite have the B-rated sheen that the first 2 had.I was suprised at 2 things which pleased me, the suspence and violence. Mostow did a better job with these 2 things than either Terminator.*End possible Spoilers*Having said all that, I'd look at it this way, on a scale of 1-10T-1 = 9.75 T-2 = 9.30 T-3 = 8.75-9.00Go see this movie, and if you've seen it, see it again!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>david77</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>film sinks under its own weight</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Having seen all three of the Terminator films as an adult, I've been progressively disappointed as the movies have come along. The first was by far the best, with real characters, a great story idea, and a solid script. The second, Judgment Day, presented a great chase sequence, but progressed poorly thereafter with weak acting and a script that steadily worsened. While the special effects were amazing at the time, the film failed where it counts most: the appearance of sympathetic characters. This last installment, which hopefully will indeed be the last, is easily the weakest in the series with very poor acting, and a script that relies mostly on special effects and chase scenes. The attempts at humor are badly needed in this movie, which was borderline boring. Even Arnold, sorry to say, seems tired of his character. With all its heavy machinery, the film sinks under its own weight.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>andrew9069</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A mere segue for T4?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>OK, you know what? Arnie can't carry a movie with the Terminator shtick anymore... it's just gotten TOO old. You gotta give him credit for looking so good at his age, but all the one liners he's forced to utter seem so contrived and derivative (as does the majority of this movie). And that opening sunglasses gag?!... Gimme a break!It was Edward Furlong and Linda Hamilton's energy &amp; desperation that brought T2 home, and their absence is acutely felt here (not to mention James Cameron's story telling and direction). I'm sure Furlong's real life personal challenges could have been incorporated to make John Connor's current state that much more striking... but oh, that would be too "risky" for such a cash-cow franchise. Clare Danes is the only actor here that could have generated some real empathy and humanity in this movie, but the poor writing does not ask her to.Robert Patrick's liquid-metal Terminator was excellent in T2 (still gives me the creeps just thinking about it) and his abilities &amp; limitations really added to the story and made some kind of sense. Kristanna Loken's coolness was great and her TerminatriX had real potential (should have had more sexy/gory scenes) but was ultimately derivative, as well. In addition, I didn't buy her upgraded terminator-ability of molting specific body parts into complicated machinery, and even less the idea that they could be permanently "damaged". (The story suffers when the writers don't follow their own rules.) God knows what unbelievable gimmick they'll come up with for T4, to try to out do the T-X!The action scenes were impressive, but I've grown tired of chase scenes pretty much altogether, each one trying to out do the last... they're just silly (e.g. Matrix Reloaded)... try spending the same time advancing the plot! (The last time I saw a decent chase scene was Ronin.) On top of that, they must have had wheels on the crane spreaders for that thing not to completely tip over right away!The only part that was really new and interesting was the end, at the military research facility, with the prototype robot tanks and planes running amok, but that was like only 10 minutes! There should also have been much more interaction with Colonel(?) Brewster, instead of killing him off as soon as they get to the research facility. It also made ABSOLUTELY NO SENSE that there were no military personnel manning that VIP bomb shelter... Very weak. However, I did like the CGI of nuclear missiles and explosions, but they didn't play up the Apocalypse enough... don't want to use up too much T4 material, I guess.Since this movie does a complete 1-80 with the deterministic aspect of fate (I thought "Fate is what you make it"?), it is a lot less hopeful than T1 &amp; T2 were. The only positive aspect about this new storyline is the relationship between John Connor and Kate Brewster, which everyone seems to like.With the amount of money they spent and the potential of the Terminator/Skynet premise, I was very much disappointed. This movie has its moments and could have been great, but it felt more like an expensive pilot for a post-doomsday TV series, and ends too early, just as things start to get interesting. Hopefully, they'll hire some real storytellers for the inevitable T4 for which this movie appears to be a mere segue. Rating for this `genre', given T2 is a 10/10: 6.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>OK, you know what? Arnie can't carry a movie with the Terminator shtick anymore... it's just gotten TOO old. There should also have been much more interaction with Colonel(?) Brewster, instead of killing him off as soon as they get to the research facility. It also made ABSOLUTELY NO SENSE that there were no military personnel manning that VIP bomb shelter... Very weak. However, I did like the CGI of nuclear missiles and explosions, but they didn't play up the Apocalypse enough... don't want to use up too much T4 material, I guess.Since this movie does a complete 1-80 with the deterministic aspect of fate (I thought "Fate is what you make it"?), it is a lot less hopeful than T1 &amp; T2 were. The only positive aspect about this new storyline is the relationship between John Connor and Kate Brewster, which everyone seems to like.With the amount of money they spent and the potential of the Terminator/Skynet premise, I was very much disappointed. This movie has its moments and could have been great, but it felt more like an expensive pilot for a post-doomsday TV series, and ends too early, just as things start to get interesting. Hopefully, they'll hire some real storytellers for the inevitable T4 for which this movie appears to be a mere segue. Rating for this `genre', given T2 is a 10/10: 6.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>Ben (SchockerGD@aol.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The sequel that breaks the trilogy curse!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've been waiting 12 years for a new Terminator movie. Having watched T-1 and T-2 roughly 50 times each, I would consider myself a huge Terminator fan.This movie delivers the best movie of the year, and its doubtful very many movies could top this (aside from possibly ROTK, should it be good).John Mostow provides an interesting, new perspective on the franchise. Having been dissapointed with most of Camerons recent work, I am very glad he did this movie.The acting in the movie is pure gold, some of the best active I've seen. Arnold, Nick, Kristanna and Claire prove to be equal to any of the actors in the previous versious of the franchise.Action scenes are equal to both T-1 and T-2 in terms of intensity, possibly surpasing both.The pacing of the movie is very well done. Having been saddened by the poor job on Matrix : Reloaded, this movie (aside from a 5 second scene) has excellent pacing. DO NOT expect to get a chance to get up and goto the bathroom.I've read that some film critics claim that this Terminator doesn't have a story, nor a heart (compared to either of the earlier movies) is rather wrong. The theme of the movie is different from T-1 and T-2.Unlike T-1 and T-2, which have messages of hope during horrible circumstances, T-3 heart lies in inevitability, fate and destiny. John's portrayl of hopelessness is excellent.*Possible Spoilers*The movie does take about 15 minutes to start up, but after that, is excellent. The direction of how the machines take over is brilliant. I was stunned at the portrayl of the actual rise of the machines. Even though there is a lack of future war scenes, the movie makes up in the beginning of the war. I doubt that any director could do a better job.The only complaints I could have in the movie is the 5 second scene where Arnold puts on his glasses for the first time, which was humorous, but not needed. As well as the fact the movie didn't quite have the B-rated sheen that the first 2 had.I was suprised at 2 things which pleased me, the suspence and violence. Mostow did a better job with these 2 things than either Terminator.*End possible Spoilers*Having said all that, I'd look at it this way, on a scale of 1-10T-1 = 9.75 T-2 = 9.30 T-3 = 8.75-9.00Go see this movie, and if you've seen it, see it again!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>david77</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>film sinks under its own weight</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Having seen all three of the Terminator films as an adult, I've been progressively disappointed as the movies have come along. The first was by far the best, with real characters, a great story idea, and a solid script. The second, Judgment Day, presented a great chase sequence, but progressed poorly thereafter with weak acting and a script that steadily worsened. While the special effects were amazing at the time, the film failed where it counts most: the appearance of sympathetic characters. This last installment, which hopefully will indeed be the last, is easily the weakest in the series with very poor acting, and a script that relies mostly on special effects and chase scenes. The attempts at humor are badly needed in this movie, which was borderline boring. Even Arnold, sorry to say, seems tired of his character. With all its heavy machinery, the film sinks under its own weight.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>nderrick</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Arnold is damn funny</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie is awesome. Terminator is not about man against machine, it is not about the end of the world, it IS about one liners spoken in an austrian accent by a man who could at one point bench two of you put together. I laughed so hard I almost got kicked out of the theatre. By the way, cameron is the wrong guy for terminator. he is too serious and deep.The new director finally realized terminator's potential as a comedy, and exploited arnold's arnoldness to create the most lighthearted and funny terminator yet. It is too bad that all three weren't like this. Anyone who complains about his movie is a loser who can't lighten up and just have a good time. This is the best arnold flick since "Last Action Hero".</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>andrew9069</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A mere segue for T4?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>OK, you know what? Arnie can't carry a movie with the Terminator shtick anymore... it's just gotten TOO old. You gotta give him credit for looking so good at his age, but all the one liners he's forced to utter seem so contrived and derivative (as does the majority of this movie). And that opening sunglasses gag?!... Gimme a break!It was Edward Furlong and Linda Hamilton's energy &amp; desperation that brought T2 home, and their absence is acutely felt here (not to mention James Cameron's story telling and direction). I'm sure Furlong's real life personal challenges could have been incorporated to make John Connor's current state that much more striking... but oh, that would be too "risky" for such a cash-cow franchise. Clare Danes is the only actor here that could have generated some real empathy and humanity in this movie, but the poor writing does not ask her to.Robert Patrick's liquid-metal Terminator was excellent in T2 (still gives me the creeps just thinking about it) and his abilities &amp; limitations really added to the story and made some kind of sense. Kristanna Loken's coolness was great and her TerminatriX had real potential (should have had more sexy/gory scenes) but was ultimately derivative, as well. In addition, I didn't buy her upgraded terminator-ability of molting specific body parts into complicated machinery, and even less the idea that they could be permanently "damaged". (The story suffers when the writers don't follow their own rules.) God knows what unbelievable gimmick they'll come up with for T4, to try to out do the T-X!The action scenes were impressive, but I've grown tired of chase scenes pretty much altogether, each one trying to out do the last... they're just silly (e.g. Matrix Reloaded)... try spending the same time advancing the plot! (The last time I saw a decent chase scene was Ronin.) On top of that, they must have had wheels on the crane spreaders for that thing not to completely tip over right away!The only part that was really new and interesting was the end, at the military research facility, with the prototype robot tanks and planes running amok, but that was like only 10 minutes! There should also have been much more interaction with Colonel(?) Brewster, instead of killing him off as soon as they get to the research facility. It also made ABSOLUTELY NO SENSE that there were no military personnel manning that VIP bomb shelter... Very weak. However, I did like the CGI of nuclear missiles and explosions, but they didn't play up the Apocalypse enough... don't want to use up too much T4 material, I guess.Since this movie does a complete 1-80 with the deterministic aspect of fate (I thought "Fate is what you make it"?), it is a lot less hopeful than T1 &amp; T2 were. The only positive aspect about this new storyline is the relationship between John Connor and Kate Brewster, which everyone seems to like.With the amount of money they spent and the potential of the Terminator/Skynet premise, I was very much disappointed. This movie has its moments and could have been great, but it felt more like an expensive pilot for a post-doomsday TV series, and ends too early, just as things start to get interesting. Hopefully, they'll hire some real storytellers for the inevitable T4 for which this movie appears to be a mere segue. Rating for this `genre', given T2 is a 10/10: 6.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-03</date>
		<username>clydestuff</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Third movie does it's best to make two previous films pointless</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>****Plot Points In This Review****I went into Terminator 3 with high hopes and high expectations. What I left with, was the same feeling I had after viewing Alien 3 for the first time. It had somehow accomplished nothing more than tarnishing the two films that had come before it. Through two Terminator films, we were led to believe that things that happen in the future could be changed, that certain things didn't have to be inevitable. With Terminator 3, we find out that was all nonsense, that there was no reason for the existence of the first two movies at all, because what's going to happen is going to happen and you can't do a darn thing about it. (just delay it for a while till we can get the next movie made). So what we end up with is three movies from the George Lucas School of prequels, though we didn't know it till now. Thanks, but no thanks for cluing us in.There are plenty of exciting action and chase sequences in the film, and they do grab your attention while they are on the screen. Still, they are nothing more or less than we've seen in any other Summer Blockbuster, so I can't recommend seeing this movie on that alone. Schwarzenegger does his usual fine one note job as The Terminator, but Nick Stahl's John Connor is so wimpy, we long for Edward Furlong to pop up and give him a swift kick in the pants. Clare Danes as Kate Brewster, Connor's future wife, is by far more interesting, and you begin to wonder how John Connor and not her ever became the one to lead the rise against the machines. It almost makes you glad that in the future a Terminator does take out John Connor. I for one would feel a lot better about it if Kate were leading my revolution. Kristana Lokken, despite not having much to do except morph, is menacing enough, but no more or no less than Robert Patrick was in the previous film. She just has the advantage of having a few more tricks up her sleeve.Will there ever be a Terminator 4? Could happen I suppose, if this one makes the major dollars as the previous films did. Trouble is, we now know the ending, and as in the Star Wars prequels, when you know what is going to happen, getting there just isn't that much fun anymore.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>When I heard they were making another terminator movie, I didn't know what to expect. After seeing this movie though, I was really impressed. I honestly believe this movie is very good. Yes some of the jokes were really lame, like the talk to the hand thing, but many other complaints people have with the movie are unjustified. People have been complaining that Nick Stahl acted "lost" in the movie. Yet that was an element of his character. Even Arnold who's now around 60 was great. Claire Danes who doesn't do many action movies was wonderful in the movie. Not to mention Loken, who is amazing, acted her part pretty well. I'm not arguing that this movie is the best terminator. Yes we all know that Cameron is a great director, but Mostow is one too. The action and story are amazing. People have been complaining about how the movie doesn't require enough thought, but seriously the third time around I think everyone understands the concept by now. There wasn't much need to explain the war. Terminator 2 did that great. This movie is an excellent movie that I believe will make an excellent addition to the terminator series. My only concern is that in order to milk the franchise, future movies will begin to suck. Let's just hope I'm wrong. WATCH THIS MOVIE!!!!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Awesome! Intense ! A must see 4 stars out of 4.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My wife and I have just seen T3 rise of the machines and we were absolutely blown away by this 3rd installment of the Terminator Saga.At first I had wondered whether the absence of James Cameron as the director would be felt but I can honestly say now, that the T3 story and character development was superbly well done by Jonathan Mostow who has earned my respect as the director of T3.The progression of the events in the film is particularly gripping and intense especially when one understands everything that has led up to the events that take place in T3. All the pieces seem to come together at a whirlwind pace and many questions are answered from the first 2 movies.The action sequences are first-rate, outstanding and compelling. The dynamic interplay and chemistry displayed by the four main characters T101, the TX, John and Kate is fascinating to watch.I highly recommend this film, which is not only non-stop action but also full of emotional depth and eye opening perspectives which characterizes great science fiction stories. I am extremely demanding of science fictions stories having been a hard core Sci-Fi fan all my life and this film passes the test with flying colors.This trilogy will take its rightful place alongside my other favorite Sci-Fi sagas such as the Alien series.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Decent action flick...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>...but not worthy as a successor to T2.Great action sequences, big explosions, great chases, and even a little self depricating humor. i liked that. there was only one scene that i felt was overly contrived. overall, it held my attention and kept the adrenaline pumping from start to finish. The acting was wooden and characters were one sided. I had trouble understanding everyone's motivation. (except for the terminator himself who by definition is one sided, wooden, and motivated). There were also some unexplained idiosyncracies that seemed like the director was going to do something more but then changed his mind. but then at the other extreme, there were some things that were very obvious, but yet were still drilled into us again and again.overall, a good action flick. but I was expecting more.</fullReview>

		<username>AMintKidIcedOver</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Terminator 3 appeals to long time fans and newcomers as well, this was a great movie.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Now im not going to give any of the movie away, because it will not be nearly as good if i do. T3 definitly takes a step up from T2 and T1 in the special effects department. Some of the special effects were absolutely breathtaking. The TX (Lokken)was brilliant as she acted so much like a machine i almost thought that she was! she has very few lines so for most of the movie, she uses facial expressions. She is also very...evil. within the first 20 minutes of the movie she kills quite a few people. Arnold comes back strong as the somewhat primitive Terminator Model-101. Again, like T2 he is greatly at the disadvantage. I think Arnold played the terminator better in T3 then he did in any of the other ones. He seemed a lot more like a machine.As for Nick Stahl playing John Connor, when i first heard that he was replacing Edward Furlong i was really angry. Furlong was the original John Connor, not to mention hes a great actor. He would have been perfect to play Connor again. But i was pleasantly suprised, Nick Stahl played the part great, and you got the feel that he was very nervous, and unstable about judgement day and his destiny from the first moment you saw him. Kathryn Brewster(Claire Danes)is Connors supporting character and Danes does a much better job then i thought she was going to do. All in All, the acting was very well done.The plot had some holes in it but not too bad. I think that they could have cleared a few things up. However, the ending stole the entire movie. I was completely stunned at the end, and it was very unpredictable....i had NO clue it was even coming.All in All, definitly worth the $9.00, maybe another $9.00 if i want to go again.....i urge everyone to go see this movie, it was great8.5/10</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-03</date>
		<username>txcheng</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Not a worthy sequel.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>T3 is more of an attempt to simply do a sequel for money. The plot line is fairly convoluted and seems more like the second part in a trilogy.Arnold is simply Arnold. He is okay, the action is as expected, lines seems more forced and the writing is not as witty as T2. Nick Stahl seems more like a TV actor and doesn't have the anger that Eddie Furlong portrayed in T2. Claire Danes does a decent job as his future spouse. Kristanna Loken as T-X is a little confusing as a character and a Terminator. Is she an improvement? She has more mechanical breakdowns than the T-1000 series. She is a babe. She tries to be icy like Robert Patrick did in T2, but to me she needs more training.My major beef about the movie is some obvious script flaws. Claire's father is in charge of an secret Air Force research lab and she along with John Conner and Arnold manage to simply waltz into this facility without even a glitch, loaded with weapons and explosives. Good security, especially in the times we live in now.The other downer is the end. How can the future be written in stone. I find this extremely unbelievable that not one thing all these people do, doesn't appear to change one thing in the future time line.I wish James Cameron was involved with this project. He is a much better writer/director for this type of genre.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-03</date>
		<username>khalsathug</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>WATCH THIS MOVIE!!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I heard they were making another terminator movie, I didn't know what to expect. After seeing this movie though, I was really impressed. I honestly believe this movie is very good. Yes some of the jokes were really lame, like the talk to the hand thing, but many other complaints people have with the movie are unjustified. People have been complaining that Nick Stahl acted "lost" in the movie. Yet that was an element of his character. Even Arnold who's now around 60 was great. Claire Danes who doesn't do many action movies was wonderful in the movie. Not to mention Loken, who is amazing, acted her part pretty well. I'm not arguing that this movie is the best terminator. Yes we all know that Cameron is a great director, but Mostow is one too. The action and story are amazing. People have been complaining about how the movie doesn't require enough thought, but seriously the third time around I think everyone understands the concept by now. There wasn't much need to explain the war. Terminator 2 did that great. This movie is an excellent movie that I believe will make an excellent addition to the terminator series. My only concern is that in order to milk the franchise, future movies will begin to suck. Let's just hope I'm wrong. WATCH THIS MOVIE!!!!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-03</date>
		<username>starman08</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Awesome! Intense ! A must see 4 stars out of 4.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My wife and I have just seen T3 rise of the machines and we were absolutely blown away by this 3rd installment of the Terminator Saga.At first I had wondered whether the absence of James Cameron as the director would be felt but I can honestly say now, that the T3 story and character development was superbly well done by Jonathan Mostow who has earned my respect as the director of T3.The progression of the events in the film is particularly gripping and intense especially when one understands everything that has led up to the events that take place in T3. All the pieces seem to come together at a whirlwind pace and many questions are answered from the first 2 movies.The action sequences are first-rate, outstanding and compelling. The dynamic interplay and chemistry displayed by the four main characters T101, the TX, John and Kate is fascinating to watch.I highly recommend this film, which is not only non-stop action but also full of emotional depth and eye opening perspectives which characterizes great science fiction stories. I am extremely demanding of science fictions stories having been a hard core Sci-Fi fan all my life and this film passes the test with flying colors.This trilogy will take its rightful place alongside my other favorite Sci-Fi sagas such as the Alien series.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-03</date>
		<username>donj73</username>

Probably the best of the 5 summer movies I have seen so far.However, If you guys own the Ultimate Edition DVD of T-2, watching the Special Edition cut with the extra scenes featuring the Sarah Connor character as an old woman will not make this 3rd part make sense.Overall, fantastic sequel....A-....Looking forward to the conclusion.</fullReview>

		<username>odysseia</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>T1 and T2 were Sci-fi landmarks but...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>when treated as a stand alone, T3 is a highly entertaining film.Ah-nold is still doing his thing in a major way. Here's hoping that the storywriters keep the twists and surprising with the indomitable Terminator. Kristanna Loken is a knockout. Her coldness and mercilessness is memorable. Nick Stahl and Clare Danes are engrossing actors. Stahl reminds me of Michael Biehn and Danes of a young Linda Hamilton. All in all, the acting is very good.</fullReview>
