It gets even more dramatic when John holds up a gun to his head just because Terminator won't do what he wants. Seriously? Quote Kyle from T1; "It can't be bargained or reasoned with". The acting...meh. It's OK throughout. Although it becomes obvious at sometimes that certain actors don't want to be there. The plot, for what it is, is OK. In my opinion this movie should have never happened, when in T2 they stop judgment day. This is mentioned in the middle of this movie, but never even questioned again. But, we got kind of a reason for this movie, whatever, let's move on. One thing that bothers me is that the killer Terminator is in the form of a girl (by default). I'm not against girls or anything, I just think the Terminator movies have a tradition of the Terminators being in the form of a boy by default, so the T-X doesn't really lead up to the franchise. Still, I kinda like that twist. This movie is good, but I still think the story ends at T2.</fullReview>

		<username>prichards12345</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>A Journeyman Terminator Movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The third movie in The Terminator series came very late in the day, and while it has some explosive, well-done action scenes and the odd dose of unexpected humour (Arnie in the Elton John-style sunglasses) it's easy to see the imagination and grasp of character the first two movies had has gone.It isn't a bad film taken on its own and its unexpected ending works quite well; other than that it's just a long chase movie. It's a pacey but rather soulless film, indifferently acted and with poorly conceived characters. Some tension is generated by female Terminator Kristanna Loken's first attack, but even this just descends into formula after a while. We've been here before in the earlier movies, and they did it a lot better.What the film really misses is James Cameron's ultra-smart direction and sassy grasp of narrative. I'll be honest and say I don't care much for Titanic and Avatar but his two Terminator movies, Aliens, and The Abyss are much admired genre classics. Johnathon Mostow's effort, in the end, does not join them.</fullReview>

		<username>kallepalli-sashank</username>

		<shortDescription>A well made action film but as far as the series is concerned,it's a mockery of Cameron's legacy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Terminator 3: Rise of the machines is a good big-budget action.Shot in wonderful locations in and around LA,breath-taking stunts and cutting edge visual effects.But as a huge fan and admirer of the franchise,I should say I was disappointed on watching this one.There are many reasons why I was disappointed on watching this one,the first being that it lacked the surreal edge that the first two films had giving you that scare as well as a fine thrill.Nick Stahl showed promise playing the role of john Connor but he had innocence written all over his face.I would have been really happy if furlong had reprised the role himself.Well,Arnie...looked way out of shape,guys who are reading this might disagree with me on this but I will elaborate it fairly..In the first two movie he was a towering 6'1-6'2 demolition man who had that grizzly killer look but here he has shrunk beyond imagination to a 5'11 and appears really odd and you can make out some sort of a difference.Plus the comical one-liners make him seem more like a clown.Even the specifics of the story have been badly altered for example,when Arnie is re-programmed by the T-X,he is about to kill Connor but Connor reminds him about his mission and that he was about to fail which gives Arnie a reminder and he shuts himself down.I found this absolute crap,because Michael biehn who brilliantly portrayed Kyle Reese certainly looked much more deadlier than he was and it was simply amazing to see the T-X take Arnie to town and for me the best scene of the movie other than the car chase was the scene where she decapitates Arnie.Well fans of this movie will definitely hate this review but as an ardent fan of the franchise I deeply felt Cameron's legacy had a much better thing in store.Its a well-made action film but not a true-blue terminator flick</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2009-12-14</date>
		<username>brando647</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Unimaginative Sequel Fails to Bring Anything New to Series...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>One of my biggest pet peeves in modern film is the creation of completely unnecessary sequels to fantastic movies. Here, we have a prime example. In my opinion, the TERMINATOR franchise would've been better off if it'd ended with the conclusion of James Cameron's TERMINATOR 2; I really wish he'd gone with his original ending showing how Judgment Day had been avoided, thereby putting a halt to future installments. Sadly, this was not the case and in 2003 Jonathan Mostow brought us the third film in the saga. The plot is nothing we haven't seen before in two other films: the future finds the human race at war with the machines (run by Skynet) and again, an attempt is made to put an end to the human resistance movement before the war ever starts. Skynet sends a new, upgraded model of Terminator to 2003 to kill John Connor, Kate Brewster (his future wife and second-in-command), and his future lieutenants. In response, the future resistance sends back another T-800 Terminator to protect him until Judgment Day passes.So, essentially what we have here is TERMINATOR 2 all over again, without some of the best aspects of what made the second film so great: James Cameron's writing/direction, Linda Hamilton, Robert Patrick, etc). The new villain, the Terminatrix, is basically a higher-tech mash-up of the first two (a weaponized endo-skeleton and a morphing liquid metal alloy) except this time it's a woman. Too much of the film feels like a rehashing of everything we've seen that most of it is forgettable until the final 30 minutes. Once Skynet goes online and Judgment Day officially arrives, the movie becomes more entertaining as we see early Hunter-Killers and T-1's rampage through a military base. The battles between the Terminators are impressive and fun to watch, but the film wanders a little too far into camp for my tastes. Some scenes, particularly the T-800's arrival in a roadside bar for ladies' night, may elicit chuckles from some but had me groaning.One element that fails to live up to the first films are the performances of the cast. With the exception of Arnold Schwarzeneggar as the T-800 Terminator (he invented the role and he really can't go wrong), the cast doesn't strike the same chord. Nick Stahl does a decent job as John Connor and seems to be a suitable replacement for Edward Furlong but Claire Danes (as Kate Brewster) spends the majority of the movie freaking out and Loken (as the Terminatrix) tries to invoke the cold, soulless killer that was Robert Patrick's T-1000 but never quite has the same effect. If a third Terminator film was really necessary, I wish Mostow and the writers had gone a little further and tried to create a unique story to grab the audience's attention, rather than feeding us the same old formula (especially with the utilization of Judgment Day as a plot point, there's so much potential there). You won't be bored by TERMINATOR 3, as it's a halfway decent action movie, but fans of the franchise who were hoping for an explosive follow-up to Cameron's T2 probably won't find what they were hoping for.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2009-06-19</date>

		<username>Quebec_Dragon</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Fine sequel not up to Cameron's previous efforts</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Terminator 3 (T3) often gets a bad rep but I think it's caused more by the greatness of T2 and how it was difficult if not impossible to beat. I didn't like how Skynet was still active even after the events of T2, it seemed to negate most sacrifices made by the protagonist and to slap the director James Cameron's work in the face (shades of Alien 3 here). However, without that, there wouldn't have been a T3 so I would have been quite satisfied if a simple explanation had been given. As it is, I had to check Wikipedia for that. The new director straddles a fine line between rip-offs and homages having at first trouble finding its own voice. It didn't feel as exciting and fresh as T2. The plot and directing were good but not as inspired as T2 either.The terminatrix was not as good a villain as the T-1000, something was missing. Arnold was still in fine form but did look older than previous films (which is unavoidable I guess ;). The actors playing Connor and Kate Brewster were quite good. The first chase scene felt a bit overlong but you've got to admire the stunt work and I don't remember that kind of truck being used in a chase before. The film and action does pick up in the second half making it more suspenseful. I loved the fight between the Terminator and the Terminatrix when they were bashing walls. I thought that was great. I also loved the bold ending very much as it's kind of surprising while also closing the big loop hole left at the end of T2. Overall, I enjoyed it quite a bit, more in the second half than the first. It's worth renting or purchasing if you're a action sci-fi or Terminator collector.Rating: 7 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2009-05-20</date>
		<username>sgtking</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>An inferior sequel, but not a bad film on it's own merits</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The first 'Terminator' film was a tough one to follow, but James Cameron came up with a sequel that was bigger and better than it's predecessor. It seemed to end the story of Man vs. Machine, but fans wanted more. For years there was talk of a possible second sequel, but Cameron opted to not be involved. In 1996 Universal Studios opened a new attraction called T2 3-D: Battle Across Time, which again sparked interest in furthering the film series, but it wouldn't really happen until 7 years later. A new director, no Linda Hamilton, and a new actor playing the role of John Connor didn't exactly have fans feeling bowled over. The film received mixed reviews and made less at the box office than it's predecessor. After seeing it for myself I can say that it's not an altogether bad film on it's own, though as a sequel to two landmark films it doesn't measure up.Pros: Good performances all around. Spectacular make-up, visual, and mechanical effects. A good score. Very beautifully photographed. Moves at a decent pace. Some truly awesome action sequences and set pieces. Though not as good as before, some of the humor is still amusing. The last 20 minutes are non-stop excitement.Cons: Plot is thin. Lacks some of the heart of the previous ones. Some of the humor is more silly than funny and therefore a bit cringe-inducing. Unlike the first two films, this one is sort of forgettable. As with the previous films you have to be really forgiving of the totally over-the-top and unbelievable action scenes.Final thoughts: The first two 'Terminator' films are so good that making a third was not going to be an easy task. Though not a bad film, 'Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines' is a big step down and not that great of an Action or Science Fiction film either. It entertains and dazzles effects and action-wise, plus the performances and direction are more than competent, so it's not a total waste. It's a decent summer blockbuster, nothing more nothing less.My rating: 3.5/5</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2009-04-21</date>
		<username>Bjelke90</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>How such a right movie can become so wrong</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I first read that Terminator 3 was being developed in mid February 2002 I jumped off my chair and cheered loudly. I remember the anticipation for the movie being huge. I was watching trailers, following updates here and on other sites on a weekly basis up until the release of the film. So I entered the cinema, only to see that someone in production didn't share my opinion on what a Terminator film is all about.A Terminator movie to me is all about the frightening, unbelievable, yet realistic story about men creating it's own doom by making smarter and smarter computers and machines. It's about the story and adventures of Sarah Connor and John Connor. It's also about having the most hardcore villains ever in firstly Arnold Schwarzenegger and secondly Robert Patrick. In the same way that Keith Richards playing guitar in the third Pirates of the Caribbean movie the casting of a Terminatrix beating up Arnold Schwarzenegger sinks a landmine into the heart of the movie. Now, Kristanna Loken is a beautiful woman, and also good at what she's doing in this film. It's only that the role she's playing doesn't work for me. I know that her role is a superior model to Arnold's and I have to think deeper than this, but there is just no way that it looks right to me when a beautiful woman kicks Arnold Schwarzeneggers but. It's a totally wrong decision in my opinion. That was the saddest part of the movie to me.And while we're at it. There's about one or two jokes in some scenes in the first two movies that never ever makes the film cross the line to being a comedic film. At parts, this movie truly is comedic and even silly. It doesn't feel like it has the right tone for a Terminator movie.The casting of Nick Stahl as John Connor isn't a perfect choice either in my opinion... He's not that good of an actor and doesn't even look like Edward Furlong a few years into the future from Terminator 2. That's why I'm so glad they cast Christian Bale as Connor for the new Terminator Salvation film since he's a much better actor and looks way more like Furlong than Stahl does.Now to the good parts of the movie. Apart from the to me obvious flaws of the movie that I presented it does have glimpses of classic Terminator quality. The core story, Terminatrix aside, is actually good. The Directing is good. Claire Danes is brilliant as well as Arnold Schwarzenegger. Kristanna Loken is good at playing a Terminatrix, it's just that her role is hopeless to succeed in my opinion. So that's a really double-edged sword. I don't think there's any woman that could have done it any better. The music arrangements are good and feel like a Terminator movie and so are some of the action scenes. I recommend this movie to those who likes to see big explosions and high speed chases, without thinking too much about what's really going on.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>so-so</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm a huge Arnold Schwarzenegger fan, or at least I was. Politics aside, I've enjoyed most of his films, even if many of them were basically no-brainer, popcorn action flicks.By all accounts he WAS a huge action star back in the day, but even with all the bodybuilding he did to get ready for T3, I still wasn't buying him as The Terminator I enjoyed from the first installments anymore. Everybody ages and even after most of the budget seems to have gone to pancake make-up and Oil of Olay to cover his wrinkles, I'm still unconvinced. I really, really wanted to give him a chance to reprise the role he so superbly fit back in 1984 and again in T2, but it's 19 years later. In the end, he's a 60+ year-old guy with a great build for his age.As for the story; it was OK. I've certainly seen better sci-fi and action films. Did it add much to The Terminator universe? Not really. It did accomplish the feat of tying up some lose ends as to how John Connor survived the nuclear attack that is necessary for there to even be a Terminator plot line. I'm not sure that the movie could have been made without Schwarzenegger somewhere in the mix, but I guess we'll all find out when T4 opens.The characters themselves were fairly cardboard and underdeveloped. Thankfully the first two movies gave some background because this one really did not help it along. I can say the the addition of a female Terminator was an interesting twist and broadened the scope of the Terminator world.If you loved the first two as I did (I've seen The Terminator at least 100 times), you'll need to see T3, just don't get your hopes too high.</fullReview>

		<username>screenman</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>The Machine Stops.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's such a pity that Hollywood seems almost incapable of realising when a franchise has run its course. So, they go on. And on.Two terminators were quite enough. The first was a creepy, almost B-movie horror flick - simple, but eminently well presented. 'Judgement Day' on the other hand, was a truly epic work of science fantasy. Between the two they used up all of the ideas associated with the concept. There was nothing else to play for. So why then not finish on a high note? Because there's still money in it; that's why. Like prospectors mining gold, they just can't accept that the vein has run out.OK, what else can we do that's new? I know; how about a female terminator? We can always build a story round that. Yes. Actually, the T1000 of 'Judgement Day' was itself capable of completely mimicking any human females it killed, so what was the point of a dedicated design? I won't go on. Objective critics have seen all of the movie's shortcomings. Only nerds sat back and gaped in awe at this one.Yes; the new effects were excellent. The tanks that had a hint of 'Robocop' about them were highly believable hokum, as were the flying machines. But we'd seen them all before, just fewer in number. The acting was plausible but hardly set the screen on fire. Arnie actually looked bored in this outing, which is something of an acting revelation for him. And the script was - well - cheesy.Judgement Day it transpires was, after all, unavoidable. It took an extra two hours of repetitive, rehashed celluloid mayhem of slaughter, truck-chases, and shattering glass to tell us that? I don't think so.Watching inadequate sequels to favourite movies is rather like seeing old friends dying from some wasting illness.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2007-12-24</date>
		<username>hasosch</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Transputing Terminators</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Since the 1930ies, Science fiction, the "genuine American fairytale" (Gotthard Günther), has anticipated a world determined by computers. The about six generations of computers built since Zuse share that they are unable to deal with circularity, i.e. self-reference, re-entry, autopoiesis, etc., because they are constructed according to classical logic which does not allow, e.g., a statement like "I am lying", since this statement is true when I am lying and false when I am not lying, i.e. it is true when it is false and false when it is true. On similar reasons, comments about sentences are excluded, e.g. "This sentence is true/false". When we hear now, in "Terminator 3" (2003), a sentence like "My command is to protect you" or even stronger: "Get away from me ... I have no choice ... I cannot control my functions ... I am a machine", then it is clear that in the case of terminators, we have to deal with a trans-classic logic and hence not with simple computers but with "trans-puters", i.e. with computers that allow self-reference because the logical law of the Excluded Middle is abolished.From the above quotation it is also clear that when a machine says "I have no choice ... I am a machine", it is self-aware on what it is, i.e. it has its own will. Its third logical value besides position and negation after the abolishment of the Law of the Excluded Middle allows this kind of machine to realize the difference between its program and its intent to react appropriately in a certain situation. Not even the newest computers can realize that, since they follow a logic in which the Law of the Excluded Middle is still valid. Here we also find the profoundest reason why terminators are that human-like (and, conversely, why they like to appear in human-like shape and sometimes lead to "hermaphroditic" creatures like "cyborgs", "androids" and others): Control of will is hitherto still a feature by which humans are differentiated from machines. If we now watch terminators, we see that trans-puters presuppose formalization not only of cognition (like classical computers do), but also of volition. But formalization of volition would imply that from a certain point on the computer would transgress its constructor. There would not be anymore, as in classical computers, a symbiosis between constructor and construction.Such "poly-contextural" computers (a term introduced by G. Günther during his work at the "Biological Computer Laboratory" of the University of Illinois) with both formalized cognition and volition would fulfill Norbert Wiener's claim for Golem-like "human-machines" uttered in his book "The Human Use of Human Beings" (1950). However, from a general point of view it is strange that cybernetics, which was established as a science since the Macy conferences in New York (starting in 1946) and is nowadays practically extinct in the academic world, seems to survive in Science Fiction which, in its turn, is anticipating future computer generations. But since "control" is a core-term of cybernetics, this science may perhaps become revitalized in times where whole continents are menaced by terrorism. If this is true, one should, however, not forget that total control must not only concern the reign of cognition but most utterly the empire of the will, too. Since this must not be done as in the case of Dr. Mabuse whose aim was simply to replace the will of humans by his own, but in allowing a machine to have its OWN will, the concept of formalization of volition only will imply both control and freedom.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2007-11-12</date>
		<username>DAVID SIM</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>The flawless Terminator series finally hits a snag</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>James Cameron's Terminator films are classics. The original was an exciting, pulse pounding adventure. A gritty SF film with a sharp edge. Then with Terminator 2, he took the framework of Pt 1, and expanded it out into an epic-sized masterpiece. We've had to wait 12 years for a third instalment. But without Cameron in the director's chair, this has had a domino effect.Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is not all bad but its a major disappointment after what we've seen beforehand. This time the director is Jonathan Mostow. And he doesn't have the intense style Cameron brings to his action films.In spite of his over-sized ego, James Cameron is an excellent action film director. His films always have an exhilarating kick. Mostow on the other hand merely 'borrows' from Cameron. If the setpieces in T3 feel eerily familiar, that's because you've seen them in the other Terminator films.T3 is not a direct rehash of Pts 1 &amp; 2. It has got a slightly different plot. But at its heart, its about the same thing. Two Terminators from the future are sent into the past. And their objective concerns John Connor. One to protect him. One to kill him.Aside from Arnold Schwarzenegger, the thread of the Terminator trilogy has always been John Connor. He was a target before he was even born. Then when he was a child. And now as a young man. Gone is the surly Edward Furlong. Now in the role is Nick Stahl.This was the first film I'd ever seen Stahl in. And to say he's disappointing is putting it politely. It's hard to believe this is the person Edward Furlong would grow up to be, and someone who will go on to be the leader of the human resistance, much less the saviour of the human race. Stahl is a positively wimpy John Connor. It's all the more surprising especially after seeing what a good actor Stahl is in films like Sin City and the underrated Disturbing Behaviour.T3 has slightly adjusted the plot for this latest instalment. But not by much. John Connor is again targeted for termination. But he's not alone. His future lieutenants are also on the chopping block. One of them is also his future wife, Kate Brewster (Claire Danes), a humble vet who gets roped into Skynet's latest assassination plan.As for the Terminators, Arnie is present and correct. But the newest addition, and the one spark of originality the film has is a female Terminator, the T-X (Kristanna Loken).Loken is sexy as hell in red leather, but she's disappointing too. She never generates a threatening presence the way Arnie or Robert Patrick did. She's supposed to be emotionless, but she's just too emotional in her inflections. She even smiles. And when she does downplay her emotions, she's just bland.Claire Danes isn't much better as Kate. I suspect she's Linda Hamilton's replacement. Nick Stahl almost says as much when he compares her to his mother. This is untrue. Hamilton had a startling presence in T2. She was always believable when packing a rifle. Danes struggles to make the part her own, and ends up buried in the A-list action sequences and special effects.The film's one ace in the hole is Arnie. At least he comes off with a degree of respectability. The Terminator is a role Arnie could do in his sleep. But thankfully he doesn't sleepwalk through the role. His cold, detached observations are surprisingly funny. Like Pt 2, he's been reprogrammed as a good Terminator, but interestingly, he's allowed some ambiguities. Things he was never allowed in the previous films.Although he's John's protector, he doesn't have to follow his orders. He can outright refuse if he wants. He is even capable of lying. Those are moments pleasantly reminiscent of his acting in Pt 1. Which made me realise how much I missed him being an evil Terminator. Arnie's OK as a good Terminator, but he's great when he's bad!At least the special effects are up to scratch. Most of them involve the T-X. She can form guns, revert to liquid, and even control machinery. As well as effect a few improvements in the chest area! But impressive as these effects may be, they don't come with the awe the T-1000 had when he assumed the pattern of a tile floor. Or gathering his shattered bits into a puddle and reassuming human form. The T-X is technically proficient, but she's curiously unremarkable.The action scenes are on a par with the previous films, but they don't feel as thrilling. The most spectacular is a high speed chase involving an artificial crane, remote controlled police cars, and LA's rush hour traffic. But the action doesn't enthrall you. It's mindless, crash-bang-wallop chaos. You somehow distance yourself from the action on display. It never grabs you by the throat the way James Cameron's action sequences did.One thing that is different about T3 is the fact that the war against the machines is about to begin, hence the title. There are a few nifty scenes involving the first wave of Skynet's robotic legions, including robots that stalk the corridors while searching out their prey. And I did like the way the film doesn't wimp out on us. The war begins in earnest, even if it never shows the devastation of our world being destroyed, making way for the terror that's to come.But still, Terminator 3 never really flies. There are nice ideas here and there, like the T-X trying to deprogram the reprogrammed Terminator, but T3 is very underwhelming. James Cameron's absence had more of an effect than I thought it would. When Mostow tries to emulate Cameron, the results are just embarrassing. A shame this once great series seems to have run dry. Let's hope the next instalment is an improvement.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2007-10-30</date>
		<username>Jerique (kris.hopson@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>You are terminated! (The series? Definitely)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Arnold Schwarzenegger comes back again as the good guy this time facing an even more powerful opponent, the T-X (Kristanna Loken).John Connor (Nick Stahl) is now an adult and its now the time of the machines beginning to take over. Judgment Day is just a day or two ahead when the movie starts.John Connor's second-in-command and wife, Kate Brewster (Claire Daines), is called into work early morning and meets John Connor (again) because he has stolen pills.Not very long after, the T-X shows up. More than just built to destroy, she is also very seductive and incredibly attractive. She is clever and adapts to her surroundings. It's hard to care about Kate, John or Arnold when Kristanna Loken is on screen.Linda Hamilton and James Cameron are both absent. Sarah has been killed off and Jonathan Mostow (U-571) has taken over directing. Generic writers have taken the writing over. Earl Boen is the only one who has returned aside from Arnold.The action was still great but the story was less interesting than the second film. It seemed they ran out of ideas. The special effects were phenomenal. It took upward ten months for a ten second shot to be captured. The stunts are stunning to watch and the CGI is hard to tell if it's real or fake.After watching behind the scenes you are shocked to find out what was real and what was fake. A few laughs here and there, some cool effects, great stunts, edge-of-your-seat action packed and a super attractive Terminatrix are the reason to not miss this one.Die-hard Terminator fans will be disappointed because it's not as great as part two but will still like it to an extent. Arnold fans, he's still funny and does another great job. But, I think that the series is mainly done. Even if they come out with a fourth part in 2009, I think this is over.</fullReview>

		<date>2007-09-13</date>
		<username>Jogilius</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Well worth the franchise.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I think this movie suffers from a nostalgia complex (just like the new star wars films). People think about the original two with a warm feeling of nostalgia and are thus in part blinded by the fact that this isn't that much different from them. This has more softening humour than the first two, and the main plot is actually nothing new, but I don't see that as a problem.Terminator 2 is better, and maybe the first one as well, but I don't think this deserves even nearly as much bashing as it has received. It has nice action scenes (even though at least one of them is a bit over-length), and the lovable humour unique to the terminator series is present. It's a great movie well worth the franchise.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2007-05-24</date>
		<username>petra_ste</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Terminates the saga</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Those machines won't give up. After sending a Terminator back in time to murder John Connor's mother in the fist movie, then a T-1000 to kill a teenager John in the sequel, now the time-traveling android assassin is a T-X (Kristanna Loken), targeting twenty-something John (Nick Stahl) and his future wife Kate (Claire Danes). With scarce originality, another android (Schwarzenegger) is sent back by rebels to stop the T-X.T3 lacks the nail-biting tension of the first two movies. Loken, with her supermodel appearance, is utterly wrong for the part, as she tries and fails to mimic Robert Patrick's superb performance as the T-1000. Patrick, with his glacial stare and sinister body language, conveyed a deep sense of menace. Loken comes across as a stunning blonde more likely to induce lust (for her looks) or laughter (for her acting). Seriously, she is bad - her stiff walk, the comical way she tilts her head... it's a vapid, leaden performance. The only clever use of the new female terminator is a brief scene where she looks at a lingerie advertisement and inflates her bust to a bigger size. It took the android only a quick glance to understand how to be more persuasive in our sexist society.Stahl is a better actor than Furlong was in T2, but writing in his scenes with Danes is cringe-inducing. Ahnold is Ahnold.Plot is nonsensical: so, is Judgement Day inevitable or not? The T-X kills Connor's lieutenants, but hey, no big deal, someone else will take their place - it's destiny. But this contradicts the whole point of the previous movies. Sooo... future can be altered, but only in a plot-convenient way? I honestly don't get it, and I suspect the writers didn't either.All would be forgiven if this boasted magnificent action, but director Mostow, who made the decent submarine flick U-571, doesn't deliver anything memorable. Say what you want of James Cameron, but the man knows his set-pieces.5/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2007-03-13</date>
		<username>selenedm999</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>better than average but doesn't live up to its name **spoilers**</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>**possible spoilers contained** Terminator 3 was roundly slammed by critics and fans alike, but having waited 12 years for it, I was prepared to enjoy it no matter what, and was actually pleased with the results.It's been 10 years since the events of Terminator 2 and John Connor has managed to avoid any traceable records, living "off the grid." When the new Terminator, a femme fatale played by Kristanna Loken arrives and kills off some of his schoolmates, it's up to JC (get it?) to save humanity, with the help of Good-Guy Terminator Arnie, and Claire Danes as former girlfriend/future wife. Violent Oedipal imagery abounds, when we find out the empty "womb"/tomb of his mother, MIA Sarah Connor (Linda Hamilton), contains some heavy artillery. The film, which is basically a chase movie like the first two, ends on a down note. Where T-1 and T-2 were hopeful about the fate of humans, the final installment lets us know that we'll all be responsible for our destruction.While not nearly up to the standards of special effects and intelligent narrative set by the first two movies, T-3 was a cut above most bonehead action flicks, and it still manages to make the audience think. It certainly missed both James Cameron and Linda Hamilton (whose ignoble death was not befitting the mother/Amazon we loved from T-2: "There are 206 bones in the human body. That was one."). I'll continue to love the series, because it's compelling and smart without losing the action, and I look forward to the next one. I'll bet Arnie won't be required, since digital imagery has come a long way. We'll see.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Terminator 3: Excellent!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>T3 is a very well made movie with amazing action and awesome special effects. It had very big shoes to fill and in my opinion Mostow delivered a good (not great) film. Sure, it could have been much better but it also could have been much worse. The TX is excellent. Kristanna Loken does an impressive job. She's not as scary as Robert Patrick's T-1000 in T2, but she still delivers. Nick Stahl and Claire Danes are alright. It's great to see Arnold as the Terminator again! Although he messes up a few lines, it does not hurt the film.The problem i do have with the film is the comedy. Sure, some jokes might be funny, but it's not at the right place in a Terminator film. The movie should have been darker and more serious.One other thing that bugged me was mistake they made about John's age. In T2 John is 10 years old. But at the opening of T3, John says he was 13 during the events of T2. I cant imagine them making a mistake like that. Overall, T3 is a solid entry in the franchise and i highly recommend it to action-fanatics.8/10</fullReview>

		<date>2007-01-17</date>
		<username>null</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>A Total Failure</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is, quite frankly, a failure.Let us start with the inferior special effects: Given that the film cost 187 million dollars to make, one would expect superior quality special effects, or, at least, high quality. However, it was not delivered.A terminator exists for one purpose: to kill. It is relentless, brutal, and every feature of its design is meant to facilitate more efficient killing. As a special effects artist, one should create imagery that captures this idea... So.. my question is... how exactly will those glowing lights help a terminator kill??? both terminators have an EXCESSIVE amount of glowing, Christmas-tree like features. the T-101 has red and green lights inside its chest, and the T-X is practically a walking blue LED. It reminds one of geeky PC with UV lights rather than a killing machine.we will also note that the T-X comes with tiny a rotary saw!! i mean, come on!! the giant stabbing sword of t-1000 provided a much better visual representation of brutality. Big, sharp, pointy objects looks menacing, blurry round things doesn't, especially when it's about 2 inches in diameter and comes with the sound FX of a dentist's drill.the physics is horrible as well, in the hand-to-hand combat scene, the T-X manage to throw T-101 for 10 meters without moving back an inch. And no, it doesn't make T-X look strong, it makes the entire scene look artificial, like a bad kung-fu movie. There is also a scene where the T-101 pulls open the door of a safe: not only is that physically impossible (if it were a real safe one most most likely pull the entire safe out of the wall) but the scene also fails to convey the message that the terminator is strong. To covey strength visually, one need to establish visually that 1) something is difficult to do and 2) the character does this difficult thing, so he/she is strong. Throughout the film the terminators perform feats of strength way too effortlessly, which takes away the realism. (in comparison, Robert Patrick's hand to hand fight scene in T2 was much much better.There are two more scenes that bugs me visually. One is the scene where T-X sends electric signals to police cars. the computer generated graphics looks like something from the 1980's. the other scene is where cathrine bruster shot T-101 and T-101 spits out the bullet. If i had designed that scene i would have had the bullet tear off a large chunk of T-101's cheek, making a wound that looks like a menacing grin while revealing its metal mandible, or better yet, tear off a piece of T-101's eye.. or, at the very least, show some blood... but nooo.. the T-101, simply catches the bullet with its mouth.. like.. some parlor trick... sigh..Aside from the special effects problem, there are script problem as well.. ill place humor is a huge problem in this movie.T-101 saying "talk to the hand" is just not funny.T-101 wearing star shaped sun-glasses.. not funny either...T-101 saying "excuse me" to T-X: not funny.cathrine bruster punching T-101 in back the same way that most girls punch guys when they are flirting with them: what is this: a romantic comedy? T-X saying "i like your car" "i like your gun"... just plain weird.T-X breast enlargement: serves no purpose. (she was gonna kill the cop anyway, not like there is a NEED for deception and doing things for no apparent purpose destroy the whole image of the Sparthan, cold blooded killing machine.) T-X always walking like she was on a catwalk.. neither funny, nor sexy, nor cool, nor menacing.T-X having a strange curious look before using her remote control ability: just plain weird to see cold blooded killing machine with the look of curiosity! In short.. the film sucks...</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2007-01-15</date>
		<username>MinorityReporter</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>One of the worst action movies of the decade!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My first question in regards to reviewing this movie is 'why'. Why did they decide to continue a story that had been finished? Why did they not get James Cameron to direct? Why, why, why? Obviously the answer is money. They wanted to use a formula which generated big box office, which it did. Unfortunately this movie completely shattered the point of the previous movies, which is very hard to do. Usually when I talk about the terminator series I casually ignore this third installment about which is hard to say anything flattering.First of all following in the footsteps of James Cameron is a hard thing to do. After all Cameron wrote and directed the first two installments in the franchise and did a wonderful job. He created two of the best action movies I have ever seen. In comes Jonathan Mostow who has but a fraction of Cameron's talent. To be fair there isn't a lot Mostow can do with the material he is given. The script seems rushed and casually ignores what made the previous movies so successful. Why the heck wasn't Linda Hamilton brought back. Her character should be treated with more respect than this. Once again the movie never should have left the drawing board.Acting wise the film has taken a huge step down. Schwarzenegger received an enormous pay check to return in this second sequel and you feel the lack of interest from his part. His performance is the least of my concerns regarding the acting, however, and Schwarzenegger gives a decent performance as he still has the stiffness and commanding presence required to be the terminator. Nick Stahl is brought in to play John Connor and while not my primary point of critique he is still frightfully dull. I don't understand why they didn't just let Edward Furlong reprise the role. Claire Danes is equally dull and much of her acting seems forced and unbelievable. Stahl's and Danes' chemistry in the scenes where they bond is pretty stale and lifeless. You don't feel the tension there was between Linda Hamilton and Michael Biehn. My primary point of critique is in the choice of villain. Kristianna Loken's villain, T-X, has none of the menace that T-1000 had or that Arnold had in the first film. It's hard to get too excited in the showdowns between her and the protagonists, sadly.Effects wise the movie has also taken a step down. Obviously the effects are more complex but they have lost their edge. While the effects were impressive they were outmatched this year (2003) by The Matrix sequels and The Return of the King. Terminator has in one stroke been reduced to second fiddle and provides only adequate CGI. One misses the ingenuity of the effects revolving around the T-1000. Once again, what a shame.All in all Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is a massive disappointment and the series really deserved more respect than this piece of garbage. One of the worst movies of the year and definitely one of the worst action movies of the decade.3/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2006-10-23</date>
		<username>galahadfairlight</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>A solid film, that moves the Terminator franchise forward</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There's no winning for Terminator 3: Rise of the MachinesNo James Cameron No Sarah Connor Different John Connor Some plot holes blah, blah, blah. and so it goes on!Some 'fans' of the Terminator franchise would have you believe that T3 is quite possibly the worst sequel ever. Frankly, its not even close to that.Sure, there is a little element of Deja Vu with T3 in comparison to T2. Again, 2 Terminators go back in time, except this time the enemy Terminator, the TX is a female.Lots of people have criticised this as "not cool to see Arnie beat up a girl", without actually using their brains and thinking that the whole point of the enemy Terminators is to blend in, and surely a slim petite female will blend in better than bulky Arnie anyday?"But T3 is only a PG rated movie and T2 was a 15 and T1 was 18."Well folks, times move on. If T1 was released today, I think it would struggle to get a 15 rating. Its not so much that the producers of T3 have scaled everything back, its simply that censoring conditions have changed since The Terminator was first released."But James Cameron, the godfather of Terminator isn't doing it."Don't forget William Wisher folks, he was as much a creator of the Terminator franchise as Cameron was. Sure, Cameron is a good director and is a good visionary, Aliens was good, True Lies was good, but what the hell happened to the ending of The Abyss? It didn't have one! So he's not without his flaws."Different John Connor." Well, as was very well documented, Edward Furlong was given time to get his act together, stop doing drugs, and sort himself out, and he chose not to.But enough of the frivoulous stuff, what of the movie itself?I liked Terminator 3. Sure, it doesn't have quite the same impact as Terminator 2, but T2 was a landmark film in 1991, the special effects were revolutionary in their day (the work on T2 made Jurrassic Park possible 2 years later). The effects in T3 are EASILY the equal of T2, its just you don't appreciate them as much as T2 because T3 merely recreates a lot of them, so the "WOW" factor is lost.Linda Hamilton didn't want to play Sarah Connor again, and to be honest, it didn't make much difference. In the first film she was all needy and pathetic, in the second she was gung-ho and slightly off the wall..... I don't see what she could have done in the third film. And quite a few people bleat that shes one of the most important characters.... well so was Kyle Reese, and that didn't stop Cameron killing him off in the first film!What I like about T3 is it puts an end to the notion of another movie going back in time again! I absolutely LOVED the ending of this film, it was as perfect as you could have hoped for. Did it make the events of T2 pointless that they couldn't avoid Judgment Day? Not really, because it would have screwed up the films time paradox.If Judgment Day didn't happen, then Kyle Reese wouldn't have been born, John Connor would not have been conceived, no Terminators would have been sent into the past, which would mean that T2 could never happen... and people criticise T3 for plot holes?????Solid performances from Nick Stahl and Claire Danes. Arnold's acting is functional (as it should be for a Terminator).I liked seeing the start of Skynets weapons with the Hunter Killers and flying Hunter Killers that you see in flashbacks in T2.The one criticism I would have is that Arnies Terminator is TOO effective against the TX throughout most of the movie. The same criticism could be levelled against the T-1000 in T2, it wasn't until the end when the TX and T-1000 both beat Arnie.Considering Arnies T-850 in T3 admits he is an obsolete model, you might of expected a bit more damage to him before the final showdown.Kristanna Loken is nearly as effective as Robert Patrick was in T2.T3, isn't perfect. Its too similar to T2 in places. T2's biggest draw was that there were two Terminators, and the previous bad Terminator in T1, became the good Terminator in T2. Well, thats pretty much the same in T3, its the same setup as T2.Its not until you get to the end of the movie that things dramatically change, and it really is a brilliant ending. But for die-hard fans of the Terminator franchise, I can forgive them for feeling a little shortchanged by the first hour of the movie, because its almost a retread of T2.What T3 does very nicely is setup the war between humans and Skynet for T4. T4 will be the logical conclusion to the series, T3 is more than just the stop gap to that, and it needed that ending to make T4 possible.I also don't think that Arnies inclusion in T4 will be strictly necessary, as his character relevance will be diminished.I liked T3 a lot. Sure, its not as good as T2 or T1, but thats as much to do with the effects of T2 being so outstanding for their time, and the storyline of T1 being the first and original.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Not as good as the first two.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines picks up years after the events of Terminator 2. Cyberdyne has been destroyed, the war has been averted, but John Connor is still afraid. He drops off the grid. He drifts from town to town while there is no record of his existence. Now, a new terminator called the T-X is sent back to kill John Connor once and for all, and once again, a T-800 model is sent back to protect him. He finds out the war has only been delayed, and now he must try to find a new way to stop it. This is a fun, action packed film, but it doesn't live up to the first two.James Cameron is no longer the director, which is the film's first problem. Next, the style is too different. A lot of comic relief was put into the script, and at some points it was highly unnecessary. The story in this movie only manages to confuse anybody that was paying attention to the second film. There are too many questions that go unanswered at the end of this movie. What I did like about this movie was that it finally showed us how the war started, and that was really cool to see. I also liked all the references that were made to the second film, like when John Connor asks the terminator if he remembers "hasta la vista, baby." Some of the humorous parts got a good laugh out of me, but it just got to be too much at some parts.The acting was pretty good. Arnold played the role that he created perfectly. Nick Stahl did a very good job taking over for Edward Furlong. Kristanna Loken does well as the new Terminator.Overall, this movie contains a lot of action, humour, and is really fun to watch, but it's a disappointment after the second film.7/10</fullReview>

		<fullReview>The problem is comparing this movie to the previous two . It doesn't quite match the impact of a James Cameron film . Did we really expect it would ? 		<username>jamesrovira</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Good, but not good enough</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's a good, entertaining film for fans of the previous two Terminator films, but it doesn't make enough of an effort, so ends the series on an anticlimactic note. For example, the new Terminator of the second film was a dramatic improvement over the Terminator of the first, while the villain machine of T3 is the same as the previous one with the exception of being a female machine that accessorizes.The adult John Connor has less juevos than even Claire Danes' character, who surprisingly impresses in this film as she does in all her work. I didn't expect her to do well in an action film and she demonstrated herself to be capable of some of the moxie of a Uma Thurman or Angelina Jolie. I hope she makes more action films. Unfortunately, in this film the action sequences make no attempt to go beyond anything accomplished in the previous two films. There is one exceptional car chase scene that rivals the freeway chase scene of the Matrix trilogy, but this expected device is the film's highlight.The film departs philosophically from the previous two: human victories were previously believed to create an open ended future. This film, in contrast, ends on a fatalist note; the future is determined and our only responsibility is to survive. For this reason this is possibly the last film in the series; all that is left is to depict the human/machine war after Judgment Day or the future they build after beating the machines.</fullReview>

		<username>tomimt</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Good sequel of the Terminator franchise</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My next comment will get all James Cameron fans angry, but then again that is entirely their problem. I liked T3 better than T2.Sure, there are plot holes in T3 where you could drive a truck through, in fact I think they do in couple of occasions, but the bottom line is, that I was entertained more by this film than I was by T2. The main reason is, that I've never been found of Edward Furlong in the role of John Connor. I thought he was a bit annoying character in T2. In T3 John (Nick Stahl) is still a bit whiny, but he wasn't as annoying.Linda Hamilton didn't return, which was a bit shame, but luckily the movie works without her. Claire Danes substitutes as a female hero, Kate Brewster, who resembles Hamiltons original role from T1 as a woman who doesn't first believe, but soon gets the situation.Arnold is back of course, as a protector as in the T2, but now he has more attitude and his role is actually a lot better than it was in T2, at least I liked him more as a "don't mess with me" kind of a robot.Kristianna Loken is more modified liquid circuit Lisa, who this time is able to generate weapons out of her limbs, as in energy guns, flame thrower and such.T3 is nonstop action from the beginning to the end. The pseudo philosophical aspects of two previous Cameron films have been dropped almost completely and the action scenes have grown bigger and more showing. There are couple of hilarious action scenes as well and Arnold's Terminator is a bit more comical, but not too much.As said, the movie has a couple of scenes which could have used more plot, but overall pros win over the cons. The movie is entertaining if nothing else.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2005-09-06</date>
		<username>ruibento</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Terminator 3 - the machines do rise, but the movie lets down</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Responsible for James Cameron's career boost, back in 1984, was the dark action-meets-horror "The Terminator". More than another thriller, this was a mark on the history of cinema, not only for its special effects and action sequences, but for its innovator story and plot. The idea of a terminator that came back from the future to murder the mother of a boy who would become the leader of human resistance in a few decades caught everyone attention. Seven years later, James Cameron did what most directors are unable to: the sequel to "The Terminator", named "Terminator 2: The Judgement Day", surpassed the first film. With the intelligent twist of turning the first film's villain into the second one's hero, along with the introduction of the teenager John Connor and the ultimate villain T-1000, drove this film to the top, making it one of the best action / science-fiction pictures of all times.Because of all of this mystic surrounding the Terminator series, I was ecstatic with the announcement of the release of a sequel to the series, "Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines". Eventually, my expectations lowered a little when I knew James Cameron wouldn't be involved in it, although John D. Brancato and Michael Ferris (responsible for David Fincher's underrated "The Game") and Jonathan Mostow would be directing it.Ten years after Terminator 2, Sarah Connor (Linda Hamilton) died of leukemia and John Connor (Edward Fulrong / Nick Stahl) became a recluse, always isolated from society. This introduces the new chapter in the Terminator series. This time, the T-850 Cyberdyne Systems Model 101 (Arnold Schwarzenegger) travels back in time to protect not only John Connor, but also a woman whose name is Katherine Brewster (Claire Danes) from another enemy: the terminatrix T-X (Kristanna Loken). But who was this Brewster character and why would the T-850 want to protect her? The answer is simple: she was going to marry John Connor and have children with him. Together, they would lead the human resistance against the machines in a not-so-distant future.Unfortunantely, it's when the existence of the terminators is justified by the authors that the plot reaches mediocrity. The excuse found for the return of the terminators is no other than fatality, the inevitability of destiny. Besides bringing up a lot of philosophical issues, this «plot twist» makes us think that all the efforts of Sarah, John and the T-800 to destroy the Cyberdyne building were completely and utterly useless. And it also makes "destiny" a fact and not an open discussion (like the existence of God, for that matter): Terminators were meant to exist and there's nothing anyone or anything can do to stop it, it's just fate. A poor excuse, in my opinion.The key-character, the T-850 (and not the T-800 as in the previous two films) is also a little disappointing. Why? After becoming a complex and almost touching character in Terminator 2, with a great chemistry between him and John Connor, the Terminator is little more than a machine and there's not the least sign of a relation between him John. This fits the plot created for this film, but it takes out something that was fundamental for the success of "Judgement Day". The only point where the authors tried to add a little humanity to the machine was when he had to face the duel between what he was programmed to do and what he «should» to: the results was terrible. At the same time, it's undeniable that Schwarzenegger's performance did put a lot of charisma into the character and it was very good to see him playing the Terminator once more. It's very hard to believe that Arnold is in his 50's, due to his great physical shape. On the other hand, the terminatrix T-X causes very little impact, despite her great attributes as a killing machine (the arms that become lethal weapons, the ability to connect to the internet and doing DNA exams in the blink of an eye, etc). It's impossible not to compare Loken's T-X to Richard Patrick's T-1000 and the second one is a clear winner. The T-1000 was a much more menacing character than the T-X and this is probably not just because of the actors, but because of the atmosphere of this film: it seems to be shot in daylight all the time, meaning that it does not have that dark side that were obvious in the other two films and were part of their greatness - the two first Terminators were thrillers and this is absolutely just an action movie.Nevertheless, despite the poor story and plot schemes, Mostow tries to draw the attentions off the plot and on the spectacular action sequences. And this is where the film's strength resides, even though the action reaches its climax early in the film. In conclusion, the third film of the Terminator saga is a close cousin to Terminator 2, since exploits the same theme of the good terminator who travels back in time to protect John Connor (and, this time, Kate Brewster) and the bad terminator who tries to do the opposite. Unfortunately, I have to admit that this was a disappointment, mostly because of its weak story and plot, but also because of the film's atmosphere (not dark at all and doesn't make you sit on the edge of your seat like the first two films did) and the lack of charisma of both John Connor (not because of Stahl's acting, but because of what Connor grows up to be; nevertheless, I would definitely like to see Edward Fulrong playing John Connor once more - after all, it was his character) and T-X. In my opinion, the emotional appeal of the terminator series along with the action sequences rescue the movie from complete failure.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<shortDescription>Its not easy prolonging Judgement Day.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Twenty-something John Connor(Nick Stahl)manages to sustain his nomad lifestyle, but danger is dead ahead when a state-of-the-art female terminator, T-X(Kristina Loken)has the mission to contain Connor. Once again to the rescue is the almost completely antiquated cyborg Terminator(Arnold Schwarzenegger)traveling back through time to run interference and provide protection for Connor as he battles Skynet and the rise of the machines. During this heavy action thriller, Connor meets his future bride(Claire Danes). Arnold is back, but the mesmerizing Loken may actually be the star of the show. There is strong sci-fi violence and some nudity providing "R" rated entertainment.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Almost as Good as the First</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I watched this film again the other night and it continues to grow on me. In fact, I upgraded my vote form an 8 to a 9. This film is so much better than T2. I know it's devoid James Cameron and some feel that this film lacked his vision and leadership. But somehow, I feel that Cameron has lost his ability to tell a story without a $100+ Million dollar budget. I like this story because it relies on and clings to the original premise unlike the second film. To me, T2 was all about eye candy and had very little to do with story. T3 returns to the gritty hard-core reality of a post-nuke world at war against SkyNet and the machines. I get chills at the end. I also love the return of the Love Story element. The first film is a love story as much as it is an action film. THat element was totally lost in T2. Congrats to the producers and all for returning the franchise to its roots.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>What a disappointment</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When seeing the trailer the first time I was astonished, it really gave me this wow feeling, and I was looking forward to see the movie. But after seeing the movie I felt betrayed, betrayed form the big Hollywood studio. And again, they showed only the best scenes from the movie. Ohh, no, not the best scenes, only the best key frames from action overloaded scenes.The runtime is too short, not even 2 hours of action was presented to the public. After the 2hour and 22 minutes of Terminator 2 I thought this third part, where the end of the world starts, will be as at least 2 hours long. Because of this lack of time the story is told a bit too fast. One action scene is right after the previous one, there is no time to think about the seen, no time to cross-link the first two parts with this third one. The talks of John Connor, where he explains where he was and what he was/is doing, well the story tellings, is simply flat, dry and monotone. Yeah, I could say it's boring. You get the info you have to know but it seems that there is no feeling behind that, it doesn't give the feeling that John is ?the" man of the future, the one and only. . .The effects, some are realistic, some are not, even Terminator 2 from 1991 has more realistic effects than this one. I'm talking here especially about the cemetery scene where T-X flies on this gravestone. The car chaise, it's fine, but hell, did the this scene where all those buildings got demolished really cost 25$ millions.The cemetery scene with Kate, the doc and the police . . . well it's to boring. Kate being at the SWAT truck, talking to the doc, being very excites, under shock, talking nonsense, the doc offers her some chill pill ( something to calm her down ), Kate takes the pill, hold it in her hands, in the other hand some water and starts telling the doc what's up. Then she mentions the name John and some huge, and the doc asks who this John is. Kate says, ?John, John Connor, an old schoolmate" and then the doc goes blank. ?You men John Connor, son of Sarah Connor" ? ?Yes" ? ?And this huge guy, and here comes the description of Arnie, calls himself a Terminator" ? ?Yes, but how do you know that" . . . and then you hear some explosions and machine guns firing. The doc turns around and sees the Terminator . . . doc shows his wondering face and says ?No, not again", takes the pill away from Kate, drinks it . . . takes another pill(s) from drinks them and then runs away. . . Kate runs after him wondering how the doc knows this bullet eating giant and tells Kate the past contacts with this Terminatora and this is where Kate should realize that it's true what John was talking about . . . this small scene, told slowly, and wisely could have made the movie a bit longer and brought some break before the next big block of explosions and fight scenes To the ARMY, well the general and co at this Computer Defense center or whatever it is act like the generals from the movies Under Siege 1 and 2.The scene where T-man is reprogrammed to kill John and John is telling him not to do it, the inner fight that the Terminator has, is simply childish and very predictable. It is somehow the low, not Terminator like.It's also funny how two people in their mid 20's can escape from human killing machines, but the well trained, educated military people are killed within a few seconds. I thought in such high security facilities only the best of the best can be the guards. O.K., a lot of computer programmers, scientists and engineers are working there, but it's simply stupid that they get killed.It seems like Jonathan Mostow used the analogy, the time-line, the art of T2 and tried to copy it to the new is story. Tried to make the same things but really failed.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The Best Terminator Movie Ever !</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There is no denying the fact that the Terminator films are the crowning glory of Arnold Schwarzenegger's acting career.When I read that part 3 was to hit the theaters soon,I was beside myself with excitement:would this be as good as the previous two ? After I saw it,I had to say:this is the best one of the three! First,Schwarzenegger is in better form than ever.Ten years since the last Terminator movie and who can even notice ?He looks as good,as invincible and what's more,he is more "human ".The script provides him with a number of one-liners that will surely cause a lot of laughs all over the world.Director Jonathan Mostow does a great job,and frankly, I must say that he has surpassed James Cameron .By introducing the " Terminatrix",he has taken the action to a whole new level.Kristanna Loken plays Arnold's ultimate antithesis,and she does a fantastic job.Throughout the film,she maintains the expression of a ruthless,brutal assassin who will never stop until she achieves her objective: to kill John Connor.She looks far more convincing than Robert Patrick did in the previous installment.It is a contributing factor to this film's superiority to the other two of the trilogy.The special effects are incredible:this time, special effects genius Stan Winston has not relied on CGI to get the adrenaline rising,but uses real robots to usher in Judgement Day.The result is a fantastic battle-scene between Arnold and the robots,and you are left thirsting for more. Nick Stahl does his best to look and act like the John Connor as a grown-up,but I don't think he leaves a lasting impression.It is Claire Danes playing Catherine Brewster,Connors' future wife, who takes the cake as far as acting is concerned-what's more,she is the only one except Arnold who fires at the attacking horde of robots,prompting Stahl's remark :"You remind me of my mother !"Danes looks more fit to lead the resistance than Stahl.If there is a fourth installment(and I pray there will be ! ),she should be cast again as Catherine Brewster.I used to think that T2 could never be surpassed,but this film proved me wrong.Outstanding work,Jonathan Mostow !</fullReview>

		<date>2005-04-22</date>
		<username>Corky1984</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Should have been better</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is another of those films that promised the world, but didn't deliver. Granted, its not bad, but it should have been so much better. The story and acting are all generally fine, but what is lacking is the biting violence of the first movie, and to a lesser degree T2. By going for a 12A rating, the team behind this accepted that it would have to be very tame so little kids wouldn't be scared. That is where it goes wrong. This film should have been an 18 without question. The action scenes are quite entertaining, but they never go far enough, and there is a scandalous lack of gore for a film claiming to be from the action genre. T3 summarises what is wrong with so many of today's films, they are antiseptic, pale imitations of their 80s forebears. Had this film been made in say, 1988, I have no doubt that whilst the special effects would have been much worse, the film overall would have been vastly more action packed. Arnie is on top form as the Terminator and the support stars are all fine, but when you look back at T1 and T2 you realise that this is not in the same league. Arnie should also have been in this film more often, that he wasn't detracts from the film. A missed opportunity.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2005-03-30</date>
		<username>DrLex</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Redundant</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I watched this movie, knowing that after T2 the only possibility to make a sequel would be to break with the existing storyline somehow and come up with something as 'Hollywood-plausible' as the trick used to justify "Alien: resurrection". So I expected nothing more than an action movie, probably combining elements from the two previous movies, using more special effects, more spectacular explosions, and contemporarily adding the obligatory woman beating up men. And I was kind of right. The one-liners were there, the spectacular chases, the CGI effects, the explosions, and a female terminator sowing death and destruction and grabbing Arnie in the crotch. *WARNING: MAJOR SPOILERS BELOW!* I won't go into detail about all the holes in the plot, because this has been done in countless reviews before. Something I haven't read during a sampling of the thousands of reviews, is that at the end, Connor says something like the Terminator has tricked them into the nuclear shelter. This would fit with the dialog right after the chase in the funeral car, when the Terminator at first didn't seem to want to change its objective of leading Connor and Brewster to a safe place in Mexico. Maybe it knew about the Crystal Peak shelter and tricked them into believing they could take out Skynet, but actually lead them to that shelter. However, the only reason why they went there, is that Brewster's dad said the Skynet mainframe is located there. Or maybe I was so confused about all the other plot holes that I got this wrong, whatever. One thing I don't understand about many of the reviews here is that people find it so obvious that this movie ought to have a T4 sequel. Maybe they didn't catch Arnie's last phrase "We'll meet again" which IMHO only refers to the fact that Connor will be killed by this very terminator in the future, as explained during the conversation in the van. Actually I believe this movie has literally blown up every chance for an interesting sequel which still has something in common with the Terminator movies as we know them. The earth is nuked, which only leaves an opportunity to make a movie which is one long battle scene in a post-apocalyptic world, the kind we saw a few of in the first two movies as flash-forwards - or flash-backs if you want. In other words, this would be something like Mad Max but then with dimmed lights and robots, which are so numerous and strong that it'll require loads of 'Hollywood-plausibility' to avoid the only real plausible outcome, being the eradication of humanity. There is no room for anything of the stuff that made the first movies interesting. But apparently, many people want to see robots beating the crap out of humans during two hours until they are all dead. Well, I don't. Not even Cameron would be able to make an interesting movie out of that. Overall, I found this a redundant addition to the two existing excellent movies. It didn't work as a sequel, nor as a tribute, nor as a parody, only as an action movie to pass the time on an otherwise boring evening.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>medic249a2</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Impressive</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While I had been hoping that James Cameron would be back to repeat his fine work with the 'Terminator' series, I was not disappointed with Jonathan Mostow's version of the latest installation. The only thing I would have added was the start of the future war - in the post-nuclear-attack world, where the human resistance starts to fight the horrifying machines of Skynet.In this latest addition to the Terminator series, the CSM-101 (Schwarznegger) returns again to protect John Connor (Stahl) - now invisible &amp; untraceable - from Skynet's latest assassin droid, the T-X (Loken), a frightening machine with multiple onboard weapons and the ability to control other machines from a distance. Additionally, Skynet has already begun its stealthy takeover of computer systems, in the guise of a computer virus. In a series of frightening and near-lethal encounters, John meets up with his future wife and co-leader in the resistance, Kate Brewster (Danes). With the T-X unable to locate John, she starts by going after future prominent figures in the resistance, one of whom is Kate's dad, an Air Force General in charge of Cyber Research Systems - which includes Skynet. They also discover that it is too late to stop Skynet from starting the horrible nuclear war that is the prelude to the war between Skynet's machines and the human resistance. However, they decide to try to at least protect General Brewster from the T-X, as the Terminator reveals he is an important resistance figure - making him a main target of Skynet's assassin droid. When they reach CRS, they discover that General Brewster's bosses in the Pentagon have lost all control of their military, courtesy of the Skynet virus that has cut them off. The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs has ordered Kate's dad to uplink Skynet in the hopes of killing the virus. Despite Brewster's reluctance to do so, he complies - and Skynet takes control of ALL the U.S. military, including the nuclear subs and missile silos! The T-X appears and guns down General Brewster, but he escapes along with John &amp; the others to his office, where he warns Kate &amp; John to head to Crystal Peak - supposedly the system core of Skynet. John &amp; Kate escape to the hardened facility and enter, aided by clearance codes carried by Kate's dad. After a narrow escape from the T-X, in which she meets an ugly end, they descend several hundred feet into the mountain to discover it is nothing more than a command center for General Staff and VIPs. The President, Congress, Cabinet and Joint Chiefs never got the warning, however, and John &amp; Kate are alone in the structure. Seconds later, alerts pour in from all over the country, as Skynet launches the USAF's ICBMs against targets in Russia &amp; China. In a frightening end sequence, missile trails criss-cross the sky as Russia &amp; China launch their counterattacks, and all over the world nuclear mushroom clouds erupt. Judgment Day has come - and soon, the war against the machines will begin.Despite the lack of an 'opening' sequence about the future war, it still leaves open great potential for a Terminator 4. The characters of the future war are introduced to us in a way that makes them believable and real. It will be interesting to see how the CSM-101 Terminators figure in the future war - we are given some hint of this in future war sequences that show huge platoons of CSM-101s deploying from Skynet bombers against the human resistance. Bring on Terminator 4!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Just a low-quality thing...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>T2 was just a snotty family movie, but you must admit it was a high-quality snotty family movie. If somebody wanted to defile everything with a gloomy hopeless secondary concocted thing (and nobody had any doubt that it would be a gloomy hopeless secondary concocted thing), they could at least try and make a high-quality one. And what did we see? We are absolutely lost in time-travel and alternative universes. That's very good. If we were not lost, we would clearly see how stupid all this stuff is. I will kill you in the future, because you will trust me after the story that was in the second film. All right. I'd like to see how he trusted him after he had told him (in the third film) that he would kill him. Or was it in one more alternative universe? Naturally, it was, in that universe all these young people had not been killed. And what will he do without them? Down with them, it's his problem, there's no fate, but he is doomed to save the humanity, so don't be afraid, he will save it! Schwarzenegger. We all know, that all his heroes are in fact one and the same hero, and he has only two ways in this situation: self-parody and self-plagiarism, and while the first is fun, the second is annoying. Now we see that he invited the third way: plagiarizing parody. Who needed it? Not me. It was just another way to make a connection with T2, and it didn't work, because it is a different film in a different era. Then, it is just badly done. Yes, they crashed much more cars, but why the chases in the first two films are as much more thrilling as less cars were broken there? They could just have rolled all those cars off a cliff without shooting it - with the same use, maybe, even with more use, because they would at least have had fun themselves. So many details that don't fit each other, the first two films and the reality, that it would be an even longer post if I tried to recall all of them. I still hope some of them are just a problem of the translation, but the other cannot be. Why such crude work? You probably remember that moment it T2, where a song begins with a new scene, "Bad to the bones" or something like that. What we find in this film? Another song, switched on in a somehow similar frame. But that one was as organic as a fragment of a song in the middle of a movie can be, and this one just strikes eardrums with no sense. All this "primary weapons", broken lavatory pans, fragile flying machines, mysterious blinking stands... It resembles a cheesy shooter video game much more than a film. Maybe, it was their primary target: to make a film easily transforming into a video game. But I am not going to play this game, neither I want to see the film many times.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Terminated</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Before seeing this film I read some user reviews because word of mouth was saying this was a weak film. I am a huge Arnold fan and love the Terminator series and think T-2 is a fantastic classic (especially the extended version - Pioneer Special Edition laser disc). This movie does nothing to improve the Terminator series. To the contrary just as Aliens 3 hurt the Alien series T-3 hurts the Terminator series. The biggest flaw is that John Connor in this film is not the John Connor of the past film. Connor was trained almost from infancy to be a soldier ? a killing machine by his mother Sarah. The type of life he lived and the things he experience would have molded who he was forever. This John Connor is a wimp ? badly directed and badly acted, if you can call it acting. Did the director of this film watch T-2? 'You remind me of my Mother,' a cowering John says to his future wife after she saves his ass. A veterinarian that acts more like a trained soldier than John; she takes control of the action, snatching up machine guns and fighting off the machines while John covers his head. Like Aliens 3 the story line of T-3, what story there is, stinks. The new female terminator ? well big deal, nothing new here ? zero edge to this boring character. At no time during this film did I feel that any of the main characters were in any real danger. For me the Terminator series ends with T-2 just as Aliens ended with Aliens 2. I hear that there is a hope to keep the series going based on the new female terminator. Good luck for me this series is terminated. I'm not joining in on the phony reviews just because I wanted this movie to be great and because I like Arnold. I tired of long boring chase scenes used as filler for weak stories. While T-2 had ground breaking special effect, T-3 offers nothing special at all. This is a 0ne star waste of time and didn't deserve a 44 million opener.</fullReview>
	</review>
